div.p: THE Deceiver Deceived: A COMEDY, As 'tis now ACTED by His MAJESTY's Servants, AT THE THEATRE in Little-Lincolns-Inn-Fields.
LONDON, Printed for R. Basset, at the Mitre in Fleet-street, near Temple-Bar. 1698.

div.head: TO Sir ROBERT MARSHAM, Knight and Barronet.
div.p: WHat shall I say, or how excuse my Boldness, in venturing to make so mean a present, and without permission too; I am full of fears, tho hitherto I have still run the same risque, and always found my Friends so good both to forgive and accept my worthless trifles: Nay even her Royal Highness shew'd such a benign Condescention, as not only to pardon my ambitious daring, but also Incouraged my Pen, why then shou'd I fright my self with the apprehension of your Frowns and Anger, when at the same time I know you to be the most Generous and best tempered Man in the World.

I look upon those that endeavour'd to discountenance this Play as Enemys to me, not that, and had the Play been never so good they wou'd have shew'd their Teeth: Yet sure, if you be so Noble to protect it, their good manners (that is, if they understand any) tho their spite remains will make 'em cease to Cavil at the Work, when such a worthy name Adorns the Frontispiece. I must not trouble you with the little Malice of my Foe, nor is his Name fit to be mentioned in a Paper addrest to Sir Robert Marsham, he has Printed so great a falshood, it deserves no Answer; yet give me leave without being thought Impertinent or Prolix, to say I now am pleased and treated by those who please every Spectator with a Candour and Sweetness not to be exprest.

If I followd my inclinations, I shou'd now proceed to recite
those Vertues which all the happy World that have the Honour to know you daily see, but that I am sure woud be the way to offend, for you scarce hate Vice more than to hear of your Merits, therefore I shall only add, as you are Happy in your Lady, Happy in your Children, which are Lovely and Hopeful as an Indulgent Parents wish can form; Happy in Fortune, Capacious like your Soul; Happy in your Friends, who love you even to Fondness: That Heaven may continue all these Blessings many succeeding Years, is the earnest and daily wish of,

closer.signed: Your most Humble and most Obedient Servant. MARYPIX.

div.head: PROLOGUE, spoken by Mr. Bowen.
div.l: DEceiv'd Deceiver, and Impostor 〈◊〉!
An Audience and the 〈…〉!
All trick and cheat! Pshaw, 'tis the Devil and all,
I'll warr'nt ye we shall now have Cups and Ball;
No, Gallants, we those tricks don't understand;
'Tis t'other House best shows the slight of hand:
Hey Iingo, Sirs, what's this! their Come●y?
Presto be gone, 'tis now our Farce you see.
By neat conveyance you have seen and know it
They can transform an Actor to a Poet.
With empty Dishes tho●'ll set out a Treat,
Whole Seas of Broth, but a small Isle of Meat:
With Powderle-Pimp of Dance, Machine and Song,
They'll spin●ye out short Nonsense four hours long:
With Fountains, Groves, Bombast and airy Fancies
Larded with Cynthias, little Loves and Dances:
Which put together, makes it hard to say,
If Poet, Painter, or Fidler made the Play.
But hold, my business lies another way.
Not to bespeak your praise by kind perswasions,
But to desire the favour of your patience.
Our Case is thus:
Our Authoress, like true Women, shew'd her Play
To some, who, like true Wits, stole't half away.
We've Fee'd no Councel yet, tho some advise us
T' indite the Plagiaries at Apollo's Sizes?
But ah, how they'd out face a Damsel civil:
Who've impudence enough to out face the Devil:
Besides, shou'd they be cast by prosecution,
'Tis now too late to think of restitution;
And faith, I hear, that some do shrewdly opine
They Trade with other Muses than the nine.
I name no names, but you may easily guess,
They that can cheat the Devil can cheat the Flesh.
Therefore to you kind Sirs, as to the Laws
Of Iustice she submits her self and Cause,
For to whom else shou'd a wrong'd Poet sue.
There's no appeal to any Court but you.

div.head: A Dialogue in the fourth Act, between Mr. Bowman and Mrs. Bracegirdle: The words by Mr. Durfey and set by Mr. Eccles.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: WHen will Stella kind and tendre
Recompense Fidele amour,
You min heart have made me rendre,
If yours come not in retour
Blank despair I can't defendre
No, no, no, I can't defendre
Grie● must kill tout les jours

sp.speaker: She.
sp.l: How can Damon love another
Who believes himself so fine,
He may talk and keep a pother.
But to change can ne'er incline
So much Charm must slight all other
Ay, ay, ay, must slight all other,
He believes himself so fine.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: Then adieu false Esperanza,
Tout le plasire de beau jours
Stella's heart keeps at a distance,
And disdains le cher effort,
She mon Ame will ne'er advance,
No, no, no, will ne'er advance
Cruel death then prend mon cor.

sp.speaker: She.
sp.l: You a Beau and talk of dying
'Tis a Cheat I'll ne'er believe,
You've such life in self enjoying
Death's a word you can't forgive
Go, improve deceit and lying
Ay, ay, ay, but name not dying,
That's a Cheat I'll ne'er believe.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: When will you prove me to know
The truth of a passionate Beau.

sp.speaker: She.
sp.l: How shall I prove you to know
The truth of a flashy Town- Beau.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: By the groans and the tears of the wretch.

sp.speaker: She.
sp.l: By his Paint, and his Powder and Patch.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: By his Mouth, and his very good Teeth.

sp.speaker: She.
sp.l: By his Sighs, and his very bad Breath.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: By his Eyes, and the air of his Face.

sp.speaker: She.
sp.l: When he ogles and looks like an Ass.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: Morbleu ma cher each part my truth will show.

sp.speaker: She.
sp.l: Mon for, mon fou I never can think so.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: Morbleu, &c.

sp.speaker: She.
sp.l: Mon fou, &c.

div.head: A Dialogue in the fifth Aact, between a Boy and a Girl, and an Old Man. Written by Mr. Motteux; set to the Musick by Mr. J. Eccles.

lg.l: WHy do I sigh and tremble so?
Why does my Colour come and go,
Is this to Love? how shall I know?
When he wou'd kiss me, I say, No, no, no, no, no.
But yet I let him kiss.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: I wish the pretty youth to see,
And yet I fear near him to be;
Shall I refuse, or else deny?
I fear I hardly shall say, Fie, fie, fie, fie, fie.
Were none but he to know.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Oh! how d'ye do, Miss? I hope I●don't scare you.
●lethinks I've no Pleasure, but when I am near you.
I don't know what ails me, but when you appear,
I feel something so pretty that tickles me here.

sp.speaker: Girl.
sp.l: Oh! Dear! so do I: Well, I'm glad you are come;
Yet I start, and I blush, when you enter the Room,
Just like our Maid, when she meets with your Groom.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Let's do as they do; seem shy, and I'll kiss.

sp.speaker: Girl.
sp.l: Oh! Law! what would Mother say should I do this!

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Hush, Fool! you must, like her, say nothing, yet kiss.

sp.speaker: Girl.
sp.l: Nay, don't you, be quiet! Grand-Father is by.
Don't let me alone— see! My head's all, awry.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I'll buss you.

sp.speaker: Girl.
sp.l: I'll scratch you.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I care not a pin.

sp.speaker: Girl.
sp.l: Nay, now the Folks see you.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Then let us go in.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Then let us go in.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.l: Why, Sirrah! Why H'us wife! how dare you do this?
I'll get a good Rod, I'll teach you to kiss.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Is there any harm in't

sp.speaker: Girl.
sp.l: Oh, pray do not Scold.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: We're not so much too Young as you be too Old.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.l: Stay till you be Married.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Pray Marry us then.

sp.speaker: Girl.
sp.l: They say when we're Married we're Women and Men.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.l: 'Tis time you should wed, if already you long.
We're quickly too old, but we're never too young.
'Tis Time you should Wed, if already you long;
We're quickly too Old, but we're never too Young.

div.head: ACT I. SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Seignior Melito Bondi, led by a Boy.

sp.speaker: Bondi.
sp.p: LEad me to my Chair, then send Gervatio hither.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: This Morning I've out-●isen the Sun, to scourge that Dog whose curst Contrivance brought the Mischiefs which destroy my Sleep: Oh! here he comes, the Coast is clear, and I'll secure it so.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Good morrow to your Lordship; what does your Lordship mean?

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: What did you mean, Rascal, to make me mad, horn mad, with this counterfeiting Blindness? but I can see your Plots, you Pander, and you shall feel my Rage.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Thus faithful service ever is rewarded; Will ye but hear me?

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: No, I've seen too much; you'll make me deaf next, I suppose, sirrah, and then set the World upon abusing me that way, Villain.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Hold and hear what I can urge, or I'll raise all the House, and lay the Imposture open.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Well, I will hold, not out of any kindness, but that I'm out of breath.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: If I am not reveng'd on ye, ye old Don, I'll be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Well, what have you to say, Sir?

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Look ye, my Lord, in the first place I'll go close to the Door, and if your Lordship offers to move or stir your Cane, I'll fly out, and this minute proclaim in Venice, that—

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Hold, I am quiet.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Then how have you the face to use me thus? Am I not privy to all your Extortions and Briberies? Have I not carried the tempting 〈◊〉 that corrupted Knaves, and excused your self from greater? Have you not 〈◊〉 a taxing power, tho' for the good of the Commonweal, was worse than a luxurious Tyrant, who thought of nothing but his Pleasures? Nay more, if the Grand 〈◊〉 would let you enjoy your Wealth, you had as live have him for your Head as his Holiness.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Well, good Gervatio, thou dost know my Failings, but 'tis the ill consequence of this blindness puts me in all these passions.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Does not your Conscience (but I have forgot, you have done, 〈…〉 would) fly in your Face, for abusing me on that account? Did not you, when the old President of Dalmatia died, come to me, Oh! dear Gervatio, I'm undone! my turn is next to that chargable Post, I shall lavish all the Wealth my whole Life has been scraping together! Then you coaxed me, Thou art ingenious, think some way I may be mist, and I'll make thy Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Nay, this is true.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Is it so? I almost lost my Eyes in reality in poring over old musty Statutes; there I found nothing but some natural Incapacity could exempt the rich Nobles in their turns: Accordingly I advis'd you to counterfeit Blindness; you did it; succeeded, Martino Cornaro is chose in your place, and I am cudgel'd for my 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Hand.
sp.p: Ah Gervatio, thou hast told the Sweets and Profits of the story, but left the bitter sting out. Whilst the Duke and Senate believed my Blindness, and I escaped that hateful Office, my Wife and Daughter do so too at home, my Wife with ogling Eyes just at my Nose, views her Gallant, and the young Gipsie lets that Bankrupt's Son, Count Fidelio, steal her Hand: This makes me mad, and wish I were blind indeed.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: For this I also provide a Remedy: You know by my care the Ladies are almost alwaies with you else; I watch 'em, let 'em look on, squeeze Hands, they'l scarce venture to make you a Cuckold or a Grandfather. Beside, my Diligence goes farther; this day the Girdle of St. Sylvester comes your tutelar Saint, for you will have a Saint too, tho' to my knowledge all your Religion lies in filling your Bags. But, as I said before, to day the wonderful Girdle comes, and will get credit, for I dare swear you see immediately after the operation.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Well, thou art a Wag; co●●●, take care of my Wife and Daughter till I dare own I perceive 'em again, and I'll make amends for my Blows; faith Gervatio▪ twas hard last night to see a Man kiss my Wife half an hour together before my Face, and when I call'd, the Baggage would take off her Lips and cry, How do'st my Dear? Then my Daughter, you know, I design for my Lord Insuls, Son to the rich French Merchant Monsieur Opulant, who by his Industry has purchas'd three 〈◊〉 Pudding French Beaux Estates.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: For a Son that as like a Iack Pudding Beau will spend it, to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Here, here, to my Chair, quick, quick, open the Door.

sp.speaker: Gonsal.
sp.p: A happy Morning to my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: 〈◊〉 Voice, I think; Gervatio, conduct me to salute him.

sp.speaker: Gods.
sp.p: By no means, my Lord, your condition excuses Ceremony, at all times 〈◊〉; the Duke commends him to you, he with much pains has got a famous 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: The Devil he has.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Now I thank thee Fortune, thou hast revenged me.
Unwilling to lose the Advice of such a Pillar of the State, has took true pains 〈…〉 experienc'd Man.

sp.speaker: good.
sp.p: I am much beholden to his Princely Care; but, my Lord, I look on this Affliction 〈◊〉 from Heaven as a Judgment, and hope by Penitence to obtain from thence a Remedy: You must●know, my Lord, I beyond measure coveted the President of Dalmatia's place, nothing but that would suffice my Ambition; nay, Heaven forgive me, I often wish'd his death.
Oh, mercy upon me, was there ever such a Dissembler!

sp.speaker: fond.
sp.p:
Now ma●● the end: Just as the old President died this Darkness fell upon
me; I have no Hopes in human Aid, but my own dear St. Silvester methoughts, in a Dream, express'd, his sacred Girdle might do me good.

sp.speaker: Gons.
sp.p: The Dream is not to be neglected, nor the Duke's Goodwill to regain the loss or precious sight, both may be try'd, i'th' Afternoon I'll wait upon you●with the famous man, in the mean time I am your Lordship's servant.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: So Gervatio, what think you of your project now? I shall have a pragmatical fellow poke my Eyes out indeed.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Fear nothing, my Lord, I'll do well enough with him. If I don't sit you Seignior for your drubbing, you shall call me Iohn a Styles.

sp.speaker: Bond▪
sp.p: Gervatio, lead me into the green Room, and see if my Wife and Daughter are up, send 'em to me.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: It shall be done, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Oh this damn'd O●nlist, Gervatio!

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Pho, pho, I'll banter him out of his senses.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Give me thy Hand, lest any of the Family should see us.

div.stage: Scene draws, Ariana dressing, and Beatrice▪

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Ha' done trifling, I'm well enough.

sp.speaker: Beatr.
sp.p: You are indeed charmingly pretty, Madam.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: How nauseous 'tis, and yet how natural 'tis to have our Women slatter us. Well Beatrice, here's a wonderful alteration since my Father's Blindness, I can put on a new suit every day, and my Jewels, laid up only for the Festival of St. Mark, may be worn now without a chiding.

sp.speaker: Beatr.
sp.p: These are great privileges, Madam, yet 'tis a sad thing to think how suddenly my Lord was struck blind.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: I swear so it is; but then remember, Beatrice, how he forbad Count Fidelio to think on me, tho' his Father was of Birth noble as mine, despis'd that Dross my Father makes his God, and left his Son only a liberal Education and innate Courage, which appears unknown to most of our Venetians.

sp.speaker: Beatr.
sp.p: My Lord dares not deny him the House, because he is of the ancient Nobility, and he has been an hour walking in the Garden, waiting your coming down, and then, I suppose, gives my Lord the good morrow.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Well, 'tis a mischievous Rogue, he has so many Tricks before my Father, yet can't I forbear joyning, nor scarce keep the Laugh in.

sp.speaker: Beatr.
sp.p: Confess Madam, are you really sorry at the Darkness has overtaken your Father?

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Why truly, Beatrice, I always say my Prayers for his Eyes restoration the last thing I do, that is, just when I am falling asleep.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Madam, my Lady sent me to tell you, your Father expects you with her presently.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: I'll wait upon her, Silvia.

That Mother-in-law of mine is a hopeful young Gentlewoman too; she takes Opportunity by the Forelock, and makes all the haste she conveniently can to give my
old Dad Horns instead of Eyes: Am not I a wicked Jade to wink at this? Why, I don't know, if I should betray her, she'd serve me the same sauce; besides, my Father married the young Creature the perfect Venetian way, only for her Portion, never saw one-another beforehand: I can't but think what a fright she was in, to behold an old Man with a grizled Beard instead of a brisk young fellow. Well, I hope Heaven makes Allowances for such a case, and my Guilt won't be great for guessing at it.

sp.speaker: Beatr.
sp.p: Your Ladiship considers what may befal your self another day, Madam.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: God forbid Wench, I hope to marry my dear Fidelio, and that Woman that takes a Man for Love deserves to be disgrac'd here, and damn'd hereafter, if but her Inclinations wayer, and she in Thought abuses him.

sp.speaker: Beatr.
sp.p: Ay, but Madam, if your Father's choice, my Lord Insuls should be forc'd upon you.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Hang him, perfum'd Poltoon, I hate him worse than a Nunnery, where they wear Hair Smocks.

sp.speaker: Beatr.
sp.p: He comes this Afternoon to make his second visit; my Lady Temptyouth says he's a fine Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: He is indeed fit for her use: Well, 'tis a strange thing a Lady of her quality should give her self the trouble, now she has pass'd the beaten Road of Wickedness her self, to draw others in. My Mother has a good Friend of her; I know my Father hates her, but his dear Interest prevails, she helps him to the purchase of many a Prodigal's Estate.

sp.speaker: Beatr.
sp.p: Madam, you forget my Lady stays.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: She's here.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: How does my pretty Daughter to day? But why do I ask? you look fresh and fair as the new-blown Rose.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: When your Ladiship consults your Glass you'll find a brighter, Madam.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Fie upon you for a little Flatterer, what your Mother!

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: 'Tis true, the Law calls you my Mother, but the World must be blind as my father, if they did not take us for Sisters.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Well, your Father's Blindness is a dreadful thing, Ariana; why, he'll never suffer us to be out of the Room.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: There is no Conveniency but has its Inconveniency, Madam.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Thats true; come, we must to him.

div.stage: Scene draws, and discovers Bondi in a Chair.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: I have a fine melancholy Life on't, thank my Stars; but should I discover my self before this arch Rogue has brought matters about, I must be the laughing-stock of Venice, besides paying a swindging Fine for deceiving the Duke and Senate in putting off the Government.— Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Are not the Women ready?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: My Lord, they are entring.

sp.speaker: Arian.
sp.p: Your Blessing, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Formality, I believe you mind your topping more than my Blessings, or Heavens either.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: How are your Eyes, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Not clear enough to see into your Heart, my Lady.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Still angry!

sp.speaker: Arian.
sp.p: Truly I hope purging my Father's Choler does him good, else surely he would never practice it so often, but that he finds benefit by it.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Baggage!

sp.speaker: Arian.
sp.p: Nay, I am out of the reach of your Cane, Sir; come, I would fain say something to divert ye, the Spleen is very hurtful to your Eyes.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Madam, my Lady Temptyouth is coming up.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: That everlasting Tattler, I would retire and shun the noise, only my being here perhaps may in part hinder your luscious Imagination from being tickled with all the Intrigues of the City.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Good morrow, my Lord; good morrow my sweet Buds of Beauty.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Pray, my Lady Temptyouth, don't put my Wife in amongst your Buds of Beauty; if she is not five and twenty, she ought to appear like fifty, that's sittest for her, and would please me best.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Lord, you're so captious: Well, I swear your Wife looks very handsom, 'tis for your sake she dresses, 'tis to look amiable in your Eyes.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Ay, now you've hit it.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Pox on him, I had forgot his blindness. (Aside) I mean, she us'd to do; now, poor Lady, she's like any Slattern. Here's my little Ariana appears as she had not look'd in a Glass to day.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Bare two hours I assure you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Well said Pride, I have a good mind to have all the Glasses in the House broke; no, sold I meant.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: My Lord, my Actions never disobey you, pray allow me a little freedom in speech.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: She that's so free of her Tongue, commonly is as free 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Oh hold, my Lord, an immodest word, nay, any hint, tho' never so darkly, tending that way, drives me out of the Room.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Your Ladiship has then a quick apprehension.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Yes, I vow, my Lord, at a Play, when no Woman of Quality else has found out a beastly wrapt-up thing, I han't show'd my Face in a quarter of an hour.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Oh wondrous modesty!

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: My Lord, Count Dresswell has a Bank Note of Five hundred pound, he can't stay till the Bank pays, and would part with it for two hundred and fifty ready Mony; will your Lordship meddle with it?

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Let him send it to Gervatio, and he shall have his Mony.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p:
I am always studying for your good; Lord, your Lady stands like any Statue, I beg your pardon, I must rouse her▪ My Dear, Count Andrea dies for you;
I swear He was in such a condition, I could not forbear bringing this Letter from him. But may your Laughter be trusted?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: With my Life, or what's dearer, my Honour.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Well, I swear he talks so passionately of ye, says such warm extravagant things, he sets my old Blood a glowing like dying Coals blow'd by a strong pair of Bellows.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: What's this long whisper, my Lady?

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Only a Receipt for your Eyes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Then why may not I hear it?

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: There's something so nauseous 'twill set you against using it. Read your Letter, Child.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: What paper is't that ru●●els.?

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Why, the Receipt, Simpleton: This man is so mistrustful. Well, but Child, I can't let this precious Receipt go out of my Hands for a thousand Worlds.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, Madam, then I'll copy it; nothing shall be neglected by me that will help my Lord. A Pen and Ink there.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: A Letter from her Gallant, and she●s a going to answer it; Hell and Furie! I can't hear it, nor can have remedy.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Heavens! what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: My Eyes smart intolerably.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Fretting, fretting; Lord, you must be patient. Madam, I beg you'd be as quick as you can, for I'm in haste.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Your Ladiship sees I'm about it.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Ah the Devil, and I see it too, and be hang'd to ye.
When you have done, Gervatio shall read it to me.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Gervatio is my mortal Enemy, what shall I do now, Madam?

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Pho, pho, write a scrip of paper good for the sight, put in Eyebright, White-Rose-water, and whatever comes in your Head.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Here's mighty Consultation about this damn'd Receipt.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: I tell you, my Lord, if you fret thus you'l never see again.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: No matter, would I could see what I wish.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: The conflagration fall upon the Women first, and leave the Men by themselves an Age longer.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Then they would be the nastiest, most helpless Creatures; ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Count Fidelio to wait upon your Honour.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Count Fiddlestick; Why did you not say I was busie?

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Well, I vow, my Lord, if you are thus froppish, all your Friends will forsake ye, a dark Room will be sittest for you.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Friendship, there's no such thing, Nature laid the Ground work of Enmity in every Mortal; indeed in some 'tis spiced over with Dissimulation; I hate this man, and yet must speak him fair.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Why do ye hate him?

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: That's a Secret.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Which I can guess at.
Now my turn's a coming.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Your Lordship's humble Servant; how does your Lordship to day?

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Well in health, my Mind is like my Sight, oppressed.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I am sorry for it.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Madam, there's your Receipt with Thanks.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: I wish it may do him good.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I shall feel good on't, methinks my Horns are sprouting already.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Madam, can't you engage my Father in a little Discourse, whilst I talk with—

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: That young handsom fellow, thou art a Rogue; I'll do't, I warrant ye. Well, you say you'l have the Bank Bill, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: I told you so once already.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Lord, you are so short one can't speak to ye, All this while Count Fid. courts, kneels, and talks to Ariana. tho 'tis for your own good: I believe Count Dresswels Estate too, you may make a good hole in't if you will.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: His Villa is very pretty, upon that he may have what Mony he pleases. Damnation!

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: What's the matter with the man? I swear you made me start, why you turn your Head about as if your Eyes were of use.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: I shall be discover'd strait, was ever punishment like mine?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: You are very uneasie, my Lord, can I do any thing for you?

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Yes, make me worse, I seldom ever knew a Wife bring Quiet or Content to her Husband.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: This is my usage ever.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: I wonder you are not asham'd, for a surly Devil; see, pish, you can't see how the poor Lady weeps.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Ay, he is blind, and I believe he designs to make me cry my Eyes out to be like him.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Oh the Devil! at this very minute she can scarce hold laughing. (Aside) You are very merry Daughter.

div.stage: Ariana claps her Fan on Fidelio's Shoulder.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: I only drop'd my Fan, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: My Lord Fidelio, how went the Votes in the Senate yesterday concerning the new Levies?

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Fidelio! why he is gone, my Lord, he only gave you the good morrow, and passed through the Room.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: That's well enough, I'll swear.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: This is abominable, but I must endure it.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Thou art a dear Angel; but, my Lady, cou'd not you contrive to get my Father away? this Gentleman hath earnest business with me.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Well, well, I'll try at that too; but which way? Gad, I've got a Bottle of Orange-water in my Pocket, I'll make the old fool believe 'tis something good for the Eyes, 'twill do him no hurt, only make 'em smart a little, that perhaps will induce him to lye down.
My Lord, can you forgive me when I own I am the greatest Beast in the World?

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: I always thought you so. (Aside) What's the matter, Madam?

sp.speaker: La. 'em.
sp.p: Here's a Bottle of precious Water, given me by the Dutchess, to be applied at all times, and I quite forgot it, I swear; I have such a respect for 〈◊〉, that at every place I am picking up something.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Yes, Gallants for my Wife.
Madam, I'll have none of your old Womens Medicines.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: By your leave, my Lord, but you shall, I know the goodness on't.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: I tell you I will not.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, be rul'd.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: True Wife, tho' she cares not if I was deaf as well as blind, yet be sure to be for any thing I am against.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Come, come, don't tell me, I swear you shall wash your Eyes with it.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: I swear I won't.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: By Heavens you shall, now I've sworn again, I'le see who'll be master.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: A Pox take ye; He struggles in the Chair, and the stings the Bottle of Water in his Face. Oh the confounded pain! Boy, here lead me to my Couch; I must e'en send Gervatio to watch 'em, that Woman will be the death of me.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha. So Ladies, what do ye think of me now?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Oh, you are the best of Women.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Heavens! yonder's Gervatio a coming, he is our mortal Foe, my Father has sent him, he had as good have staid himself.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Let me alone, I'll send him away, I'll lay a Wager.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Fidelio, step behind the Skreen, whilst my Lady trys her Power, he'l tell my Father you are with us.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I will, Madam; dear Lady Temptyouth, if thou canst effect this, I'll have thy Statue made in Brass.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Brazen-face! could you think of no other Metal? go, be gone.

Your Servant, good Don Gervatio, you are come luckily to receive my Instructions, you must immediately carry to my Lord Dresswell Two hundred and fifty pounds, and take his Bank Note for five hundred.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Your pardon, Madam, my Lord sent me to stay here.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: And your pardon too, Sir; I am sure your Lord would not lose such a Bargain; and he must have the Mony presently, or he'l sell it to some-body else.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Indeed I heard your Master say he would have it.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: He's a Prodigal, and may give me something out on't: here's no Men, what should I stay for? (Aside.) Well, I'll carry it presently.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Presently, nay, you must go now, this very Instant, now.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: What, does your Ladiship intend to ravish me?

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: When I thrust thee from me, Fool. Come, good Gervatio, make haste, because I undertook my Lord's business, and I love to go through stitch with any thing I meddle with: Be speedy, come, I may do ye a Kindness another day.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: I must be gone, there's no disputing with her.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Appear absconding Knight, appear.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Be gad, my Lady Temptyouth, you have charm'd me so, you shall have a Kiss with as much Ardour as if you were but sixteen.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: O sweet young Gentleman, Heavens bless him! You are happy, Madam: Come, I must do more for you yet, Time's precious; my Lady Olivia Bondi, let you and I go into the Garden, and consult about that Receipt.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: You'l find what I have done in it is to your satisfaction. Daughter, your Servant, I'll keep your Father from sending for you as long as I can.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Madam, I am yours and my Lady Temptyouth's most humble.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I am her Slave.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Well, you are a couple of dear Kittens, bless you both.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: My Lord, you have talk'd of Flames and Fires, and Darts, and the Devil and all, but how shall I be convinc'd 'tis not the Hundred thousand pound I am like to be worth kindles these Fires and Passions?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Why faith, Madam this way; let's marry without your Father's Consent, and he'l turn us out of doors, then I'll beg for ye, fight for ye, starve for ye, dye for ye.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Thou art an honest Lad, but I don't like starving, 'twill be apt to take away all your Appetites, and you won't care for me.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Oh no, my Love to thee is implanted in my Soul, and were my youthful Arms reduced to very Bones with the worn Skeleton, I should hug thee to my Heart, as my chiefest Blessing and divinest Treasure.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: 'Tis pretty to hear a young fellow one loves talk thus, but this wont do, Love and Plenty crown the circling Year with Pleasure, but where either's wanting, Content scarce ever appears. Is it impossible to get Gervatio to our party? He is cunning, and can rule my Father.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I'll try; but, Oh!—

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: You want a Bribe; come, be not asham'd of your poverty, since your noble Father wasted his Fortunes in being always in Arms for the defence of his Country against our common Enemy the Turks, the ungrateful Senate ought to have took you to their care; but since neglected, accept of this without a blush.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Bound by innumerable Charms, by Obligations unaccountable, when I cease to love thee, may Heaven and all my Peace of Mind forsake me.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Try Gervatio, tell him that I'll for ever be his Friend.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Madam, I will with joy, and urge whatever eager love can to my Soul suggest.

sp.speaker: Beatr.
sp.p: Madam, my Master raves for you like one mad.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Then I must go.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: My Lord Insulls, that Rival; but why name I him? I know your noble Soul despises him.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Rest in that secure, I loath the man, my Father's power shall force my Death sooner than Consent: farewell.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: 'Tis Death to part, tho' but for a moment; Is there a time, is there that white day in Fate when I shall call thee Wife? let others scoff, think the Matrimonial Bonds uneasie, term it
sp.l: A Hell, a Pit, an endless painful Snare,
The Heaven I covet is to wed my Fair.

div.trailer: The End of the First Act.

div.head: ACT II.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: WEll, your Importunity and the Count's has prevail'd, I'll vow I blush to think on't, through a back-door into the Garden, the hour that my Husband sleeps, a young Gentleman; faith, Madam, 'tis very scandalous.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Fiddle fiddle, scandalous! if you have the Pleasure, much good may do the World with the Scandal.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: You'll stay with me, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Madam; I left my poor Girl at home not well on purpose to come.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: What kin is that young Lady to you, Madam?

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Her Mother was my Friend, to tell ye the truth, she is a Bastard, I have bred up several, and help'd 'em all to good Husband, or Gallants, which is better.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: A charitable Lady you are. Hark! I hear a noise, 'tis he, I swear I shall ●●sh to death.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: I never heard of any-body dy'd of that Disease; here's the man, look what a well-built person 'tis.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Ladies, your Servant.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Did you come in 〈◊〉 observ'd, my Lord?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Yes, Madam; but have had a little misfortune, I've broke the Key in the Door, and know not how I shall get out again.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Here's a Fool now is taking care to get out before he is well in, mind your business, I'll get ye out, I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Pardon me, Madam, 'tis my dear Olivia's Honour I am careful of; for my self, I'd wade ten thousand Dangers only to touch this beautious Hand.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Why that's well said, kiss it now, or else you do nothing.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: A thousand and a thousand times.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Well, I'll in, and watch the old man's motions.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: You won't leave me, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Indeed but I will, I cannot stay a moment longer.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Shall we waste the time in talk, Olivia? Need I tell thee how much I love thee? Wast thou not torn from my longing Arms by an inhuman Father, and given to the wither'd ones of richer Bondi? Yet tho' I am denied whole Draughts of Love, I'll snatch the precious Cordial when the blest minute gives it, and devour it eagerly.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Away, my Lord, think whose I am, think of my sacred Vow, I dare not break it.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Your Vows first were made to me, no matter whose you are, this hour is mine, and shall be spent in richest Love, Love that has so well reveng'd my Cause, and as your cruel Lord snatch'd her from these fond Eyes, so Fate has now depriv'd him of his own, he only cannot view your unequal Charms, which dart on every wishing gazer Joy.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: If Judgments do hang upon my wretched Lord, shall I by Falshood wound deeper than his Fate?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Who e'er crys out of pain they neither feel nor apprehend? Think Olivia, my Olivia, for I will please my self, and call thee mine; think the vast Charity, the mighty Kindness, that saves my Life, and hurts not Bondi.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: The Man is mad, to bid a Woman think; no, talking Deluder, when we think we never yield. Now I have thought on the fatal consequence, and resolved from this minute to grow wise; that I have took the opportunity of my Husband's blindness, and seen you often, was due to your injurious Wrongs; for witness those Stars that smiled not on our plighted Faiths, I ever found you constant, and I lov'd you for it.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Oh sweet Confession! and if you love me, will you not bless me too? the Argus Eyes of Jealousie are useless, the watchful Dragon that should guard the golden Fruit now sleeps for ever.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: But Angel, Honour is still awake, that secures my beating Heart, yet I will fly the charming sounds that are familiar there, but do not follow me, I charge ye, do not, lest ye meet the everlasting Anger of my Eyes.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Not follow thee, when my Veins are all on fire! yes,
sp.l: Thro' every Path of this delightful Grove,
Till my warm Sighs her Honour shall remove,
And fill her panting Breast with yielding Love.

div.stage: Scene changes to the inside of the House.
Enter Gervatio, a Servant to him.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Seignior Gonsalvo sends word, the Oculist is sick, and cannot come till to morrow.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p:
Hum,— then my Revenge is lost, for the Girdle comes before that
time. Did not I see Actwell cross the Court just now into the Kitchin?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Call him to me.
That fellow that plays tricks for his Victuals, perhaps, for a Pistole, may do my business; my Lord knows him not.
Leave us.

sp.speaker: Actw.
sp.p: What's to be done now? What am I sent for to Master Steward?

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Actwell, my Lord, was to have a famous Oculist come to day, and he just sent word, he cannot; 'twill put my Lord so damnably out of humour, there will be no enduring it; cannot you pretend to be the Oculist, get a Launcet, look into his Eyes, talk Nonsense, make him believe you'll do Wonders, but when it comes to the upshot, I'll enter, and prevent your touching him? You must say you came from the Duke and Gonsalvo; I'll give thee a Pistole.

sp.speaker: Actw.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir, I am daily obliged here, I believe I could do it well enough, only I don't understand those damn'd cramp words those Quacks have.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: O say any thing; half an hour hence come to the Wardrobe, I'll give you an old-fashion'd Cloak, that you may look like an experienc'd man full of Years.

sp.speaker: Actw.
sp.p: I will, Sir; the Film, the Tenders, the Devil, I'll look into a Book of Anatomy, and get some terms from thence; I will be sure to wait upon you, Sir. This was happy for poor Actwell.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: To fright him, is that all for such an intolerable caring? Gad, if the Devil was not wanting in a Temptation, I could do him a greater Mischief.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Your Servant, Don Gervatio.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Sir▪ my Lord's asleep.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: 'Tis you, not your Lord; I am come to— but e're I tell my Suit, receive this Purse, a young Lady's present.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: You banter me.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Indeed I don't Gervatio, you can see, tho' Melito Bondi's blind and might have seen, I live but for Ariana's sake, the kind Maid meets my Flames, and generously returns 'em; my wretched Fortune hinders me from following the way my Love proposes, taking her my only Blessing from her Father; 'tis in your power, Gervatio, to assist us in making up, if but a moderate fortune, you can perswade, decoy, do any thing with the old man,

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: The Temptation I wish'd for is come. (Aside) My Lord, your Offers are made in a happy time, for I was just designing to wait on the young Lady, and proffer her my Service.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Are you real?

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: By all that's good I am, my Master has beat me into a right understanding.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: What shall we do with this Lord Insuls, Gervatio?

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Why, as he's made of Cork, we'l set him a floating, and return him to the rest of the mercurial Gentlemen in his own Country. Well, my Lord, leave your Affairs to me, and if I don't bring Ariana to your Arms, and more Bags than three Men can carry, my Ears shall be at your mercy.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Well, thou art a dear Rogue, and shall command my Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: My Master rings; trust to me, and be happy.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Your Servant.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Yours.

div.stage: Scene draws, and discovers Bondi a rousing from a Couch, a Boy with him.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Where's my Wife and Daughter?

sp.speaker: 〈◊〉 'em.
sp.p: Here, here, my Lord. Well, I believe your Wife is the best of Women, we three have been all at work in the outer Room, and I'll swear poor Olivia 〈◊〉 in upon you twenty times, she is so fond, for all you are a naughty man, and use her so barbarously.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Well said Telltruth.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Here's a Tale of a Tub indeed, where is she now?

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: I fancy gone to take a turn in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Boy, go call her.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: What's the Boy a Fool? 'Tis not convenient for him to go, he shan't go.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Heyday! my Lady Temptyouth, are you to order every thing in my House?

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: I will order things when Decency requires; look, to end Disputes, here the good Lady comes.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: I heard the Bell had rung, and hasten'd to my Dear.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: My Devil.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Such Answess would make a Woman mad.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: You have got a pure colour, Olivia.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Pho, walking apace.
But, my Lady, how shall I get him out, there's no opening that Door, and the other way lies through this Room?

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Why, what's he afraid on, isn't my Lord blind, where is the Fool?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Speak softly, walking at the Door.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Let me come by; Who have we here? my French Taylor has follow'd me hither about the Girl's Stays; Oh the Impudence of these Country-men! Monsieur, go to my House agen, I'll come home presently.

div.stage: C●un● Andrea passes over the Stage, and kisses Olivia's Hand.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Pardon a moy, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Pardon a moy kether, rude Brute! I'm sure I am not like most Quality, I owe him nothing.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Count Andrea, my Wife's first Love! Oh, the Garden, the Devil! curst, curst Gervatio.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: What mean these starts of Passion? do you want Gervatio?

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: I want a Halter.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Wou'd you had one then, you're cross enough to deserve it.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Some-body, I'm sure, does.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: My Lord Insuls is just arriv'd.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Let me desire all this Company, except my Daughter, to retire, I've made up the business with my Lord's Father, there wants nothing but a Visit or two, which formality requires: Come, Mrs. Crooked-rib, will you walk into the next Room?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: I'm ready to wait on you.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Oh, my Lady Temptyouth, now my Plague's a coming.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Have Patience, Child, and I'll send Fidelio to thy aid.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: D'ye hear, Mistress, receive this Lord as the man I have unalterably resolv'd shall be your Husband.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: yes, Sir; what a tone's that in! I think you're but too well, an Estate, a Title, and an handsom fellow.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Pray add an empty Pate.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Goodlack, Mrs. Flippant, any other Woman would have leapt at him; upon my Blessing use him as he deserves. Come, my Lady Temptyouth.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: As he deserves, that is to be cudgel'd. Now I had rather have the Visits of fifty Gossips from a drunken Christening, than the Plague of this Prince of Fops: Hang it, I'll bridle my Inclination, let him run on with his Vanity, then burst my Sides with laughing at him.

div.stage: Enter my Lord Insuls, with several Attendants.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: This is prodigiously opportune, by the Muses, to find your Ladiship alone, Powderwell, adjust my Garnature, I beg your Ladiships Pardon, that I do any thing of this kind before your Ladiship; but there was an uncivil Wind, as I passed the great Court, has blown me into the very disabilee of the vile Mob.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: I can't perceive an Error in your Lordships Dress.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: Your Ladiships very humble Servant, by the Muses, I am all in confusion; I beg your Ladiships Pardon (takes out his Pocket-glass.) For this freedom before you, but 'tis that I would not appear negligent in your Ladiships presence.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: What a nauseous Fool 'tis.
My Lord, methinks you're very well.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: 'Tis your goodness, Madam, poison me if I don't look like a Carr-man; I look most abominably, by the Muses: Was your Ladiship never in France, Madam?

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: There a Man will keep his Chamber three days, if his Complexion is out of order; they are not arriv'd to that nicety of Perfection here.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: 'Tis pitty your Lordship does not instruct our young Nobility.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: I am not sparing of my Advice, Madam; some I find very tractable, there's my Lord Dresswell has consulted my Judgment in laying out above a brace of thousand pounds in Clothes, I believe the World, especially the Ladies, will own 'tis to his advantage.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Yes, and a good help towards spending his Estate, which, I'm inform'd, will be gone before he's five and twenty. (Aside.) None doubts your Lordships skill in those Affairs.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: But of all the moving lumps of Earth, commend me to the English, those awkward Imitators, by the Muses, Madam, there's scarce one in ten understands the Dress, the Dancing, the Singing, those chief parts of a Man of Quality; the Duce take me if I was not afraid they had infected me, and when I return'd into France, liv'd a whole month retir'd, had all my Masters, practis'd every Coupee before I durst appear among the Ladies; yet, by the Muses, I know not how long I shunn'd my self; methought I had the Brutal Plague upon me. I beg your Ladiships Pardon for troubling you with a description of the dull Northern fellows.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Every thing your Lordship says is agreeable, I observe very pretty Asseveration you have, by the Muses.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: Does your Ladiship like it? Indeed I think it sounds better in the mouth of a Man of Quality than Damn me, Rot me, and such Porter-like Expressions.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Oh, better much, my Lord; I have a shrewd suspicion you that mention the Muses so often have a familiar acquaintance with 'em, and write.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: I write like a man of Quality, to please my self.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: I dare swear 'twill ne'er please any-body else. (Aside) Wou'd not your Lordship oblige me with the sight of some entertaining Poetry?

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: By no means, I beg your Ladiship's Pardon, 'twill spoil Conversation, I can send your Ladiship several gilt Quires scribbl'd over, if your Ladiship's a lover on't; most of what I write is Satyr upon ill drest fellows, and then, by the Muses, the nauseous Subject makes me so sick, I cannot forl●●●r being spiteful too, and criticise upon what others write.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: That's the fault of all great Wits, methinks their good Nature should balance their Judgment.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p:
Good Nature, Madam, why that's only the civiler word for a Fool: If your Ladiship did but see in France how the poor Poets at a new Play sneak, and wou'd
creep into an Augur-hole; when I come in, by the Muses, I have often wish'd my my self a Woman, that I might have gone in a Mask, and not frighten the little Dogs (that write for Bread) out of their Wits.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Does your Lordship never write Plays?

sp.speaker: Its.
sp.p: Yes, often, but I could never get either of the Houses to play one.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: What's the reason of that?

sp.speaker: Its.
sp.p: Can't your Ladiship guess?

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: No, I protest.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: It will favour too much of Vanity to tell you.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, you have set me a longing.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: I must run the risque of every thing, rather than deny a Lady: Then truly, Madam, I believe they think, and that wisely, should they once play a Play of mine no other would ever be receiv'd afterwards, and, you know, a man of Quality can't be their Drudge.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Very true, that is a substantial Reason.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: But, Madam, I know not how you have betray'd me into these things, when I design'd to have imploy'd my minutes much more agreeably, in telling your Ladiship, I adore you to an infinite degree.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: His Courtship will be worse than all the rest of his Nonsence, Heaven send me a deliverance. (Aside) My Lord, a person of your merit cannot value one so unpolish'd, Nature has neglected me, and I have neglected Art.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: Oh ●ie, Madam, this is Blasphemy, they are both Rivals in your Perfections. But were it what you say, which I positively deny, by the Muses, when I have the Honour to call you mine, I say, if you did want Instructions, the rectitude of your Dress should be my care.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Rude Fool, I have no patience.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: Madam, you seem uneasie.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: It's want of Breeding then.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: Gad, I believe so too, for I never saw a Woman in my company so before. Madam, you I break your Fann.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: No matter, 'tis paid for.
I can act the dissembling part no longer.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: She's strangely alter'd, jealous she can't keep me to her self, her Fancy's at work; there's nothing out of order in my Wig sure.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Oh Fidelio, do something, do any thing to that Animal, and let me be gone, for I am teased to death.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Gad, I know not what to do but affront him; flatter him I can't, 'tis not in my Nature.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: Every Hair, I protest, is in as perfect Symmetry as my Features, as I was saying, Madam.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: As I was going to say, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: Sir! hey, what rude Brute have we here? (Aside. Friend, wou'd you speak with my Gentleman, or the Groom of my Chambers? there they stand both.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: There let 'em be damn'd both; no, 'tis you, Essence and no Brains, I speak to; Shadow of a Man, vainer than Woman, emptier than the Plumes thou wear'st. Thou thing, dost thou pretend to court that Lady which went out just now?

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: If the Lady went away, I suppose she knew you better than I, and avoided so rough a fellow.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Insolent!

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: Something near my Name, tho' still without my Title.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: Barbarous!

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Did you not receive a Letter signed Fidelio, which told you my Birth was noble as the first Venetians, tho' my sunk Fortunes were now my Foe, yet Ariana, that all-generous Maid, through my dejected Poverty smiled on my constant Love, and gave me Hopes▪ I beg'd ye to desist, else let you know, that my Life must first be had before the glorious Pride; read you not that Letter?

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: Something I do remember of such a Paper, but I saw it was a Man's Hand, and gave it my Valet to peruse, and asking him if there was any thing in it to divert me, he said, No; so I ne'er thought on't more.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Now you have heard the Contents, pray dismiss your numerous Attendants, and meet or go with me to the Field that lies behind the Lemon-Grove, where this Dispute shall instantly be ended.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: What's the man mad? wou'd ye have me ●ight in this Wig?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: Oh Heavens! any thing towards a violent motion would raise such a Dust out on't, I shou'd be kill'd in a mist.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Pho, pho, we'll call at my Lodgings, and you shall put on one of mine.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: Poison me if ever I heard the like, prithee where dost think I was bred? wear another man's Wig, when the best Barber in Venice knows, that after he has alter'd, amended, reform'd, and modell'd a new Wig for me half a Year, it is with much perswasion I try it.

sp.speaker: Fid,
sp.p: Here's a deal of Nonsence, come, what a pox must we do then, for ●ight you I am resolv'd, or kick and post you thro' the Streets of Venice.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: By the Muses, I know not what to say; in France I have a Campaign for the bloody purpose, 'tis so necessary, yet so becoming, several Marshals of 〈◊〉 have been ready to pull me to pieces for it; there I have also sighting Shoes, sighting Gloves, sighting Sword, &c. and, in fine, can in a moment be equipp'd 〈◊〉 Travelling now like a Man of Quality, and to obtain my 〈◊〉, I left my Warlike Habiliments behind; if you'll have Patience, I'll send post for 'em.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Incorrigible Fool! No, Sir, I give you but till to morrow to answer me, and that you may be sure not to forget the Affront, there's a Remembrance upon your Nose, [〈◊〉 him by the Nose] and another upon your backside. [kicks him. and a warm one for your Cheek.

div.stage: [gives him a box on the ear.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: Well Tarpaulin, Monster, half Fish half Man, I'll be reveng'd, I will Villain, there's those shall punish ye; hey my Attendants.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Now this fellow goes directly to my Ariana's Father; sure her Love will inspire me to counterplot one Rival-fool.
sp.l: By Force or Wit his Claim he shall decline;
If Heaven is just, the Virgin must be mine.

div.trailer: The End of the Second Act.

div.head: ACT III.

sp.speaker: Arian.
sp.p: HUmph, my Father here already! I did not think he had been come into this Room; he can't see me, and I will steal softly through, he shan't hear me neither.

div.stage: (As she's about the middle of the Stage.)

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: What shall I do now? I'll counterfeit Madge the Dairy-maid's Voice, for if he knows me, I shan't get from him the Lord knows when.
'Tis I, my Lord, I did not think any of the Gentry had been come into this Parlour, so I went this way to serve my Pullein; Ise warrant Ise come no more here.

div.stage: (Runs stamping off, Bondi throws h● Cane after her.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Oh, dissembling Baggage! Are all blind men served thus? Two such Women as my Wife and Daughter are enough to make twenty Men mad.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: My Lord, some Company from the Duke, and with them the famous Oculist Gonsalvo spoke of.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p:
So, now my greatest Misfortune is falling upon me. (Aside. Call my Family together, and go to Gervatio, bid him, as he values his Life, consider what I said to him, and hasten to me. (Exit Servant.) The Imposture known, Boys will hoot me out of Venice; then, to have an unskilful
Man put me to intolerable pain, perhaps real Blindness, (Stamps) Oh! I shall go mad.
sp.stage: Enter Olivia, Actwell dress'd like a Doctor, and several others.
sp.p: I know not a Face of those, sure my Friends are afraid to come, the Operation is so dangerous.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: How d'ye, my Dear, were you in a passion just now?

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: I found by Instinct you were near me, and that made me Horn mad.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Humph, I am a Fool to speak to you at all.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: You are a Fool, a gross one, because you dissemble poorly; but, blind as I am, I can see thro' it.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: What does he mean? he can't be jealous of Count Andrea, because he never saw him. (Aside.) Well, my Dear, I consider your Condition, and will bear with your peevish Hamor. Here's some Gentlemen, and a famous Oculist, sent by the Duke, to look into your Eyes.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Peace, Scriech-owl, I am in pain enough already.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: I hope he will give you ease, my Lord.
Sir, please to look into my Husband's Eyes.

sp.speaker: Actw.
sp.p: Fear not, my Lord, putting your self into my Hands, shou'd I, or some of those Gentlemen that have travel'd with me, recount the Wonders I have done, you wou'd rejoyce at your good Fortune in meeting with me. There's the Emperor of Germany's Aunt, threescore and ten, was led about stone blind twenty Years; I came, and in a few weeks time made so perfect a Cure, that she has since work'd her Nephew a Point Cravat. I take out Specks where no body else can see 'em.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: That will be my Case.

sp.speaker: Actw.
sp.p: Oh, the sweet Duke of Tuseany! what a Film did I clear his Eyes of! the Good of Mankind prevail'd with me, or else 'twas hard to get from him.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Mr. Doctor, I don't doubt your Skill, but I had rather wait the Will of Heaven for the restoring my Sight.

sp.speaker: Actw.
sp.p: By your Leave, my Lord, I am Heaven's Instrument, and here's the Duke's Command to do my best for you. Gentlemen, draw near, and hold him in the Chair, while I look in his Eyes.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: I shall be murder'd here.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Pray, my Dear, be rul'd.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Iezabel!

sp.speaker: Actw.
sp.p: Ay, ay, here it is, a huge Speck, just growing on the Ball of his Sight, the worst of black Catarachs, but I shall out with him: let's see, how is t'other Eye? Oh Lord, further gone! Well, you may bless your Stars that you met with me as you did, or else you had never seen in this World agen.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: I am contented with my present condition, and desire to speak with the Duke before you meddle with me.

sp.speaker: Actw.
sp.p: My Lord, your condition is a desperate condition, and the Duke shall see some of my Art before you speak with him.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Oh the Devil! I shall be ruin'd, where's this Dog Gervatio?

sp.speaker: Actw.
sp.p: When I have couched your Eyes, my Lord, you must lye upon your Back for six weeks, and be fed with nothing but a Feather.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Why you us'd him most inhumanly, I fear he'l complain to the old Gentleman. Heyday, what have we here, my Father in the hands of the Philistins? Stay, don't you speak till some time after me. What's the matter, Sir?

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: So, here's another of my Comforts, with her Beggar at her Tail. (Aside.) The matter! here's a Fellow will mangle my Eyes whether I will or no.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Can I serve you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Yes, if you I beat that fellow.

sp.speaker: Actw.
sp.p: How! beat me, that have the Badges of all the Princes of Europe, Asia, Africa, and America! Come, come, I find my Lord's mad; pray, Gentlemen, help me to bind him in his Chair.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Murder, murder! then, to tell you the truth, I am not blind.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Nay, then 'tis time for me to appear.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: I tell you I am not blind.

sp.speaker: Actw.
sp.p: Pho, pho, this is only his fear.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Nothing else, you may assure your selves.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Well said, Mother, I think you may be pretty confident on't, for no man that cou'd have seen would have had Patience to have born what you have acted before his Face.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Make way there, let me come at my dear-lov'd Master, the sacred Girdle of St. Silvester, brought by two holy Men, is just arriv'd; a new unusual Light struck thro' the Hall, and I could see as if I had ten pair of Eyes, so light, so glorious was the place; 'tis lodg'd i'th'Chappel, whither the Priests desire you all to repair, and invoke the power of the Saint.

sp.speaker: Actw.
sp.p: A Pox of those Miracles; d'ye hear, if your Saint does you no good, don't send for me, for, by Belzebub, I'll not come at ye.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Rarely perform'd, I'll speak with ye by and by.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Thy Hand, Gervatio, I tremble every Joynt of me; thou art a Rogue, but I forgive thee. Come, Gentlewomen, tho' I believe your Prayers signifie but little.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Madam, what think you of this miraculous Girdle?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: I don't use to have a great Opinion of those things, but we shall see what Wonders this will do.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I think the whole Story is all a Wonder.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: When your Father cry'd out, he was not blind, I was terribly frighted.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: I believe you was, Madam.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I'll try to engage Gervatio farther in our Interest, then we shall know all.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Come, come, if we stay longer, I'm sure we shall be miss'd.

div.stage: Scene changes to my Lady Temptyouth's House, Lucinda at a Dressing-Table.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: How is it, my Blossom? Let me see, has not sitting up at the Ball last night spoil'd thy Complexion? No, not a bit: Oh, I cou'd kiss thy pretty Eyes out.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: How can your Ladiship tell my Complexion is not spoil'd? I have got both my white and red on, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Oh, that's nothing Chicken, there's a Vivacity strikes through, and thy pretty Eyes are as sprightly, as if thou hadst drank Nectar this Morning. Come, what Conquests did you make last night? You know there lies my Pleasure, to hear of your Victories.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: There was my Lord Dresswell said a thousand foolish things to me.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Pho, hang him, he's going down the World, he's neither fit for Husband nor Cully; think not of him, I charge thee, Lucinda.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: I shall never think of any without your Ladiships directions.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: That's my good Girl; well, but was there none else?

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Yes, there was the Duke's second Son, he only blush'd when he came near me, trembled when he touch'd my Hand, danc'd with such concern, that I thought he would have fallen.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, the Fool's in love, I'll put him down in my Table-book, he may prove considerable.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: As for the rest, some swore they hated me, others I was not pretty; so thro' a Medley of Confusion every one endeavour'd to express their Admiration.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Thou art a dear, dear Charmer; well, I swear I love thee better than any of the little Creatures I ever brought up before.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: I thank my best Mother.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Nay, thy own Mother was a pure good Woman, only her barbarous Friends turn'd her out of Doors for having such a pretty Rogue as thee: I kept her, poor Lady, till she died.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p:
My Lady Olivia Bondi sends to tell your Honour, That St. 〈◊〉 wonderful Girdle has restor'd my Lord Bondi's Sight, for which, at present, they are paying their Devotions this Afternoon, the Duke's Musick, Balls, and all Divertisements
〈◊〉 will afford, 〈◊〉 my Lord Bondi's House; the Ladies desire your Honour's company, and the 〈◊〉 Lucinda's.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: We'l wait upon them, our Service to the Ladies. (Exit Servant. Poor Olivia, her 〈◊〉 Husband's seeing will be but bad for her and Count Andrea: ●●ang't, 'tis setting our Inventions a little more upon the stretch, and we shall out-wit him still. Ha! I have a Thought come into my Head for thy advantage, Lucinda. Here, 〈◊〉, bring my Girl's best Head, and all her Jewels. Oh, Lucinda, if thou canst play one part to a Masterpiece, I don't doubt making thy Fortunes for ever.
Ah, Tifflewell now show thy utmost Art, and make thy Mistress charming as an Angry.

sp.speaker: Tiff.
sp.p: I warrant ye, Madam, such a piece of Youth and Beauty to work upon, and fine Clothes, let me alone to make an Angel of her.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: If thou canst but humour it.
Give me Instructions, Madam, I am not accounted backward.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: No, no, thou'rt a dear forward Girl as Heart can wish; this would oblige our Friends▪ prove an everlasting Provision for your self, and ravish me with Joy.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: But yet you won't tell me what it is.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Dear Tifflewell, put another Jewel here.

sp.speaker: Tiff.
sp.p: Pray your Honour let me have my own Fancy first.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Lucinda shall sing, and Lucinda shall dance, and if they two, both in perfection, won't charm him, the Devil's in't.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Sing and dance, is that all? I have done that often enough to no purpose already.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Yes, yes, thou shalt do more than that, my dear Chicken, can't you put on a world of Affectation?

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: With all the ●ase in the World: Alas, Madam, It was born with me, and I have as much ado in some measure to overcome it, as I have my Inclinations towards the eating green Fruit.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Affectation is a mighty Art, my Dear, and those pretty Eyes must be manag'd a thousand several ways, severe, languishant, ogling, darting their Beams, cast around, and if they chance to meet, a Lover's thrown with wondrous haste and modesty into your snowy Bosom.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: My Eyes, dear Mother, ever were at my Command, but never let Fools in them read my Heart: Thus I have look'd upon the man I scorn'd, thus on him I would not have believe my Love impossible, tho' hard, to gain; kind and coming Looks I seldom use, I'm not arriv'd at that Age yet.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Dear Girl, your Aptness prevents the Care I would have undergone in your Directions, but you must be very sure to rail, commend neither Man nor Woman, either in their Persons or Dress, except my Lord, to whom you are all the while addressing.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: I am glad 'tis a Lord, for I hate to take pains about a fellow that has no Title.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: He has not only a Title, but an Estate, and every thing I cou'd wish for thee; Are you quite ready?

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, do I look killing?

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Like a Cherubim; come along.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Oh my Olivia! Bondi's Sight restor'd deprives me ever of the Light of those dear Eyes: I ne'er believ'd those Miracles told by canting Priests, now Heaven, to punish my Incredulity, has sent one that robs me of all my Bliss, and nothing but the crowd, the noise of this wondrous Girdle brought, could have gain'd my Admittance now.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: My Lady Temptyouth is our Friend; beside, these warm Desires will soon grow cool, and then you will be glad of an Excuse.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Never, Olivia, never; my Youth, my Life, my Fortunes, all are dedicated to thee.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: [within] I say, my Lord, you shall not press into your Ladies Chamber till she has word we are here.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: [within] Sure this Woman intends to vex me stark mad.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Oh Heavens, my Husband! what shall we do?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: I'le get into the Closet.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Alas, he has the Master-key.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: [within] 'Tis but in vain, Heaven has restor'd my Eyes, and I will see what is done in my House.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Good my Lord, under my Toylet, quick, quick.

div.stage: Enter Lady Temptyouth, Bondi, and Lucinda.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: And what wou'd you see now, your good Lady all alone, returning Heaven Thanks, I dare swear, for the wondrous Blessing you have receiv'd.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: I'm sure I saw the glimpse of a Man follow her to her Chamber.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: A Man with me!

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Pho, Child, 'tis Jealousie, he takes thy Shadow for a Man.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: I'le look into this Closet, but not enter it, lest you juggle him from under your Petticoats.

div.stage: [Olivia makes signs to Lady Temptyouth, that he is under the Toylet.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Come, is your Maggot over? will you down into the Dining-room, hear the practice of Musick, and my Lucinda shall give you a Dance.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Dancing be damn'd, I'd as live see a Monkey leap from Tree to Tree.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Not even his Eyes agen will put this man into a good Humour. Well, I hope we have a noble Entertainment, according to the old Proverb, a Miser's Feast is always the best; will ye go down, or no?

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: No, I'll dine here.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Seem willing, madam, 'tis the only way to prevent him.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: With all my Heart, for I hate much Company: Here Diego, and your fellow, carry this Table to the Dressing-room-door, a-top of the back Stairs, there Sylvia can thrust it in, and bring the Side-board hither.

div.stage: Enter 〈◊〉, who carry off the Table, Lady Temptyouth going by the side.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Have a care you drop nothing.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: You are wondrous forward, perhaps I won't dine here when all is done.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: 〈…〉 the old Gentleman does not know his own mind.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: 〈…〉, are you setled in yours?

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: If I am not, my Lord, my Years excuse it.
One of your bringing up, my Lady Temptyouth, I suppose, because she is so brisk.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: I'm not asham'd to own her; yes, 'tis my dear Girl.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: An't please your Honour, my Lord Insulls desires to speak with you, on very earnest business.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: I believe I may dare venture to go, for my Gipsie would never have been so-willing I should have di●ed here, if the Coast had not been clear. (Aside) Shew me where he is.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: So, he is gone, I hope the Count is safe.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I saw him slip down the back-stairs as soon as ever the Men were out of sight.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: How do you do, pretty Lady, I scarce dare speak to you before my Husband, he's so peevish.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Peevish, indeed I never saw such a cross old man in all my life.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: What would you do, my Dear, if your pretty Youth was confin'd to such an one.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: O, I'd quickly send him to Heaven in a String; I'd have half a score Gallants; Madam, if I did not seaze him to that degree, that in a months time he went to sleep with his Fathers, hang me for a Fool.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Thou art a Mad-cap.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Let us go down, for I have a Design upon that Lord Insulls, which I'll tell you as we walk.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: I am ready to wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Was ever such Impudence, such Disobedience practis'd under one's own Roof? Mercy on me! what will this World come to? A wanton Wife and an undutiful Daughter! the Plagues of Egypt were meer Flea-bitings to them.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: Nay, I thought your Lordship was not privy to the Affront, because I knew your Lordship first propos'd the Match; indeed never man of Quality was so abused; I would have fought the fellow, but that I fear'd, by his Carriage, he was a Scoundrel, and would disgrace my Sword.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Oh, 'tis a vile Wretch, but I'll be so reveng'd on him. My Lord, if yet you think my Daughter worthy, the Ball just ended, a Priest shall make her yours for ever, tho' indeed she ought to expect your Scorn and Hatred.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: My Education taught me never to bear Displeasure against the fair Ladies, I shall wait with much Impatience and Joy till you summon me to the fair one.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: My Lord, I beg you would go to the Company, whilst I send for my Daughter, and give her a Lesson, for I fear she was at the bottom on't. Call Ariana.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: I will leave ye pray be not too severe upon the Lady, I have a great respect for her; but for that rude fellow, by the Muses, he deserves kicking and pumping.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Did you send for me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Yes, Mrs. Manybetters, and none worse; how you are trick'd up! the Dancing, not your Father's Sight restor'd, is your Joy: Are not you a Cockatrice? dare you look me in the Face after what you have done?

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Done, my Lord!

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Yes done, Minx, you and your beggerly Bravo abuse a man of Quality, Fortune and Honour.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Has the Baby been to tell its Tale then?

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: D'ye make a Jest on't Huswife? Hear what I say, and mark it: This night thou shalt be my Lord Insulls Wife, or else, by Heaven, I'll turn thee loose into the wide Streets of Venice, stript of all Means, all Comforts, there to get thy Bread amongst thy fellow-prostitutes, but never own thee for my Daughter more.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: These are cruel sounds, they strike through my soul, and dead my sence. Oh, Sir, hear your only Child; you us'd to say you lov'd me, if I have lost that Blessing, let Compassion plead, heap on me all punishments, spare me but in this; let not my Youth be condemn'd to what I loath, to such a Fool, a Blockhead, Coward.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Rebellious Witch!

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Consider, Sir, you force me on the Road to Hell, for my strong Aversion needs must lead me on to Murders, Adulteries, or such horrid Crimes that will surely plunge me there.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Let go, stand off, for as I have a Soul, this night you are married, or ten thousand real Mischiefs shall befal thee.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p:
Mischief is already on me, lasting Mischief, fix'd for Life, a Husband whom I shall ever hate and all the World will still despise, all my cheerful hours are for ever fled, Fate has not one in store: Then let their Revels shake the House
with noisie pleasure, fix'd on this wretched Earth, so stupified I'll grow, till I can work my melancholy Thought to fancy I'm a piece on't.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: What's here, my charming young Mistress on the Ground, she that us'd to enliven all the World, now, when there reigns a general Joy, sunk in Sorrow? rise, dear Madam, rise.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: I'll try that; come Madam, what's the cause of this dejection? did I not receive from you a noble Present? Come, pray believe me yours, and tell me what's the matter.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: If I durst trust thee, but 'tis no Secret; my Father has sworn I this night shall wed Insulls.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: And you had rather have Fidlio.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Rather, oh, there is no comparison

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Smile then and you shall; but, 〈◊〉, I'll do nothing without you are merry.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Were I rid of the fear of Insulls, I could leap over the Moon.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Let me see, does not this Lord Insulls pretend to Poetry?

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Most intolerably.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: And is he not vain upon it?

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: As all Wou'd-●e-wits are.
Then, dear madam, let your Troubles end, and be as brisk as your sweet natural Temper incites, I warrant your Lumber of a Lover safe enough from disturbing you when the Ball's done.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: O that I could believe thee▪

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: You'l believe me when by my sole contrivance the Parson hath conjur'd you between a pair of sheets in Fidelio's Arms; ah! methinks I see you laid on the delicious Scene.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Go, you are a Talker: Then I am to know nothing of your plot.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Not till you hear of the success to the Company, sweet madam. Yonder the Hall's as full as it can hold, the Musick's a thrumming, the Gallants are ogling, my Lady Temptyouth as busie as a Bee, there wants nothing but you to crown the Assembly.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: I'm gone; remember, if you fail my Heart's broke.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Let your Heart be as light as your Heels, and fear nothing, fair Lady.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Take this and be careful.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: I would not be old Bondi's faithful Fool agen for the World, there's some delig● a Gusto in serving these young generous souls: Well, Brains, if e'er you'd do 〈◊〉 service, let it be now, help me to baulk this foolish Lord.
sp.l: Fix soft Ariana where her Wishes tend,
So she secures a Lover, I a Friend.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

div.head: ACT. IV.
div.stage: Wherein is Bondi, Count Andrea, Lord Insulls, Fidelio, and several other Gentlemen; Olivia, Ariana, Lady Temptyouth, Lucinda, with many other Ladies.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: COunt Andrea is your Guest, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: No, he is my Guest, sure for the many Estates I have help'd you to for half the worth of 'em, you may allow me to bring one Friend.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Your Ladiship's alwaies my Friend, I thank you. Come, why don't this Dancing go on? if your Heels wou'd wag, 'tis to be hoped you would be tir'd and ha' done once.

div.stage: SONGS, and a DANCE by Lucinda and a French Beau.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: (to Lucinda) Heavens, Madam! I have seen nothing so ravishly mine, nothing like it, by the Muses; since I left Versailles, 'twou'd be impertinence to the highest degree to ask if your Ladiship was not bred in France.

sp.speaker: Luc.
