sp.p: Oh, the Paradise of the World bred there, my Lord: Yes, my Mother was so nice she had me nurs'd in France; I warrant she would not a let me suck'd any other than French Milk for a Principality.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: A witty Woman, by the Muses, and charmingly pretty: Then your Ladiship understands the French Freedom and Gallantry? According to those Rules, pray Madam, number me amongst your humblest Servants.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: With all my Heart, there's a Favour to distinguish you. (Gives a Ribbon. No more words now we are observ'd.

sp.speaker: La. 'em.
sp.p:
Well done, my Lucinda, she's at him, i'faith, my Maidenhead to an Eggshell he's her own. (aside.)
To Oliv.) This is dull doings, Madam, I wish I could part the Company, send those Gravities to tope their Noses, and get our selves a little freedom.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: I wish you cou'd, Madam; poor Ariana has not spoke a word since she came into the Hall.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: I'le try: Well, now I vote that the Gentlemen and Ladies that have danc'd retire into the drawing Room, and recruit with Sweetmeats and cool Wines, and the old Dogs take up their Smoaking-room, and drink lusty Chiaux, Bagrag, and the warmest Wines my Lord Melito Bondi's Cellar affords.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Spoke like an Oracle.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Spoke like a Devil, putting all the young ones together; but this is the last day of her Reign, for I'le forbid her my House, tho' I lose Ten thousand Crowns a Year by it.

sp.speaker: An old 〈◊〉.
sp.p: I like the motion well, for, by my holy Dame, I am tir'd with seeing nothing but hip hop, hip hop.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Come, come, you as becomes you, your Age and Quality first.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: The Devil take thee.

sp.speaker: 〈◊〉. Tem.
sp.p: Now pair all, and follow your Leader.
I'le let Ariana see I stomach the Affront.

sp.speaker: To Socin.)
sp.p: Madam, may I crave the honour of your Hand?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes Gallant, 'tis at your service.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Did you see my Fool strut by with Lucinda? Now he is vain enough to fancy I will be jealous.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: He is not worth a Thought.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Alas, you know not how formidable he is; my Father, with the dismal'st Threats that Man could utter, has sworn to marry me to him this very Evening, as soon as the Ball is over.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Hell and Furies! I'll cut his Throat immediately.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Gervatio with much assurance promis'd me a deliverance, have a little patience, such desperate Attempts will ruine all.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Dost think I'le stand by and see thee lost?

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Nor will I tamely yield; but now let's be calm, and the Company, methinks I have great Faith in Gervatio's Promises.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: And I have Faith in thee; but, oh, if power should overcome madness, Despair and Death would seize me.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Where are you, Chickens? Come hither, or spight of me, the old man will rouze ye.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: We come.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Mr. Stretchwell, and Mr. Heardouble, you understand your business.

sp.speaker: Stretch.
sp.p: Ay sure, or else we spent our Lives to very little purpose.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Well, here I plant ye, and bring the Lord Insulls; if he owns he made the Libel call'd The present state of Venice, you know what you have to do.

sp.speaker: Heard.
sp.p: Yes, yes, truss him up for Treason.

sp.speaker: Stretch.
sp.p: Hurry him away to Prison without Bail or Mainprise.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Right, behind those Hangings conceal your selves, I'll bring him as soon as possible.

sp.speaker: Stretch.
sp.p: His business shall be done I'll warrant thee, old boy.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: And you rewarded.

sp.speaker: Heard.
sp.p: Well, Brother, we are a great Prop to this State, Verice had long ago moulder'd into its watry Foundation, if we Informers had not supported it from ten thousand Treasons.

sp.speaker: Stretch.
sp.p: Dost think think this Lord Insulls is guilty or not?

sp.speaker: Heard.
sp.p: What matter is't? he's rich▪ and we'l fleece him.

sp.speaker: Stretch.
sp.p: I hate a poor Dog, that pretends to be in a Plot.

sp.speaker: Heard.
sp.p: Impudent Varlets! when they han't Mony enough to pay their Fees, they'l undertake to turn Governments upside down.

sp.speaker: Stretch.
sp.p: Hark, I hear a noise, to our Posts.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: My Lord, I humbly ask your pardon, for drawing your Honour from the bright Assembly, but I understand you are in a fair way to be Heir-apparent to all my old Master's Wealth: I have been a long and faithful Servant here, and may prevail with old Bondi to drop more Bags than he design'd.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: Honest Gervatio, thou art kind, but the young Lady uses me most scurvily, by the Muses, she must expect, whom I am her Husband, that in return of her scorn I treat her with Indifference.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: She deserves it; good Heavens! slight such Worth as yours!

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: Nay, by the Muses, Gervatio, without boasting, I may say, all the Courts in Christendom have admired my Person, Parts, and Dress.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: No doubt, my Lord, your Lordship has such an Oath, sets my mouth all on Water, by the Muses: Oh, I had a devilish smatt'ring at 'em in my Youth, but hard Fate threw me upon Units, Tens, and the Gargon of Accounts, when I long'd to have been rhiming: I am sure your Honour writes, O that I cou'd be so happy to peruse some of your incomparable lines.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: What I write is all light Satyr, if your Fancy's that way, I can send you Reams of cover'd Paper.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Is it so light Satyr, i'faith? ha, ha, ha, nay, then I smell a Rat indeed, they sed 'twas a 〈…〉.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: What 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: As if you did not know, that exquisite, elaborate, most ingenious piece, 〈◊〉 7. 〈…〉 of 〈◊〉, wherein the Satyr is so winning, so instructive, so reforming, as I may say, that the Duke is pleased with it to that degree, he has promis'd his fair Daughter's Pict●●e-set round with Diamonds, in a Gold Chain that goes fifteen times about the Neck to the Man that will own himself the Author.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: He, he, he, does that Trifle make such a noise? Alas, I have writ Five hundred better than that.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Impossible, but we owe this to your Lordship, I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: Yes, the Lines are mine, but I care not to expose my Name, I want not the Duke's Present, Gervatio

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: No, my Lord!

div.stage: (Both the Informers run out, and clap two Pistols to his Head.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: What's the matter, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Stretch.
sp.p: Hold your Tongue, Sirrah, make no noise nor resistance, if you do, one of these sends your Poetical Brains into the Air immediately.

sp.speaker: Heard.
sp.p: Here's a Rogue for ye, Brother! he ●ed he had made Five thousand Libels on the Duke and Senate.

sp.speaker: Stretch.
sp.p: Ay, ay, he shall have his Reward, a Halter instead of a Gold Chain.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: Why Gentlemen, to tell you the truth, I did not write the Verses.

sp.speaker: Stretch.
sp.p: Every Malefactor can deny his Crime.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: Oh 〈◊〉! what's the meaning of all this?

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Heavens! my Lord, I am as much amaz'd as you, these fellows have betray'd me, they told me the Poetry was ador'd by the Duke and Senate, and I should have a swindging Reward if I could discover the Author; my business was always to ●et Mony, my Lord, and I hoped to have done my self a Kindness and your Lordship an Honour.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: Yes, you have honour'd me, I thank ye, put me in a fair way to be hang'd: Good Gentlemen, remove these horrid Instruments of Death a little further, they put my Peruke quite out of the curl▪ and my Body in such violent sweats, I shan't be able to come near the Ladies agen this Fortnight.

sp.speaker: Heard.
sp.p: Oh, there's no Ladies where you are a going, come along.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Fear not, my Lord, I'll get you Bail.

sp.speaker: Stretch.
sp.p: How, going to whisper the Prisoner! here's another Fiddle will make ye dance farther off.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: O Lord, O Lord, I never could endure the Nose of Belzebub against my precious person.
Come, let's have him the back way, lest he alarm the 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Stretch.
sp.p: Shall we put him in the Dungeon?

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: Good Gentlemen, consider my Ball-clothes.

sp.speaker: Stretch.
sp.p: Here's a Fellow taking care of his Clothes when his Life is in danger.

sp.speaker: Heard.
sp.p: Well, Brother, according as his pockets are lined, he shall be used.

sp.speaker: Stretch.
sp.p: Ay, ay, away with him.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: Pray leave haling me, I'll go quietly.

sp.speaker: Stretch.
sp.p: You'd best.

div.stage: Scene draws, and discovers Olivia, Lady Temptyouth, Ariana, Lucinda, Ladies; Andrea, Fidelio, Gentlemen; a Side-table, with Wine.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Madam, shan't we beg a Song of the charming Lucinda?

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Not till my Lord comes, I have told ye my design.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: And I like it extreamly.

div.stage: Enter Bondi, the old Senator, and a Priest.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Heavens! look Fidelio, what●s that stalks behind my Father, a Priest?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: The Devil it is.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: I fear there's mischief's toward.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: As the day has passed in Joy, so, I hope, 'twill have a joyful end, for I design before all these Witnesses to marry my Daughter, the young Lord Insulls is the Bridegroom, his Father and I long ago concluded it, only my Infirmity deferred the matter.

sp.speaker: Old Sen.
sp.p: Ay, let's have a Wedding, the thoughts on't makes my old Blood dance.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Rather the strong Wines work upon your weak Brain.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: The Devil! all my design's ruin'd, and poor Ariana's Heart broke: fiddle faddle, my Lord Bondi, this is nothing but thriftiness, now the Fragments of the days Revels must serve for the Wedding Supper; no, no, old Gentleman, don't mistake your self, we'l have another Festival for dear Ariana' ● Marriage.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: My Lady, you have a large rule in my Family, but in this Affair, upon my word, I'll be Master.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: My Veins with kindling Ruge are all on fire, what shall I do, my Ariana? I'll meet and stab him as he enters.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Have a moments patience, he appears not yet.

sp.speaker: Luk.
sp.p: What, must I lose my new Servant, Madam?

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: So it seems, Child.

sp.speaker: Luk.
sp.p: A welladay! but hang't, while Fifteen has not overtaken me, I'll never spoil my Face with grieving.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: If I have any power, my Lord, I beg you wou'd oblige your weeping Daughter, in delaying this unwelcome Match.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Rest assured you have no power with me, and all you say against it hastens my Resolves; use your Prayers and your Commands where you bestow your Charms, I am cold, as I have ever found your Love.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: This shou'd be Jealousie, but what can give him Ground for a Suspicion?

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: O, where's my Lord?

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Here; what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Oh, my Lord, the worst News, the saddest Accident! Oh! my Heart will break for the poor Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: What Gentleman? explain thy self.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Gentleman did I say? no, no, not a Gentleman neither, 'tis a Lord.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: My Heart bodes Comfort.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Torture me no longer, dear Gervatio.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: That hopeful Sprig, oh! I can't get it out, my Lord Insulls.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: What of him?

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Alas, the overflowings of his Wit has undone him: In short, my Lord, some base Trappanners, Informers, of which this State swarms, sent for him from this Company, and got out of him, that he made that cursed Libel, The present state of Venice, which has so exasperated the Duke and Senate, that they have resolved to hang the Author.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Hang him!

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Ay, hang him, Sir; my Bowels earn for the young Bud of Quality.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: What a Devil had he to do with Poetry, that Leprosie of lazy Minds, that Weed of Nature? Had he not Estate and Title? must he covet the Begger's Entail, Parnassus Lands, and be damn'd to him? Plague consume all the rhiming Fops in Christendom.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: What, your worthy Son-in-law!

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: He makes me mad.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I cou'd worship thee, Gervatio.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: I must be rude, and desire the Company to break up, whilst I go and try my Interest to release this jingling Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: The Gent.
sp.p: My Lord, we are all your humble Servants.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: You two go round, and you will find the back-door of the Garden open; when my Master's gone I'l● call ye.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: We'l be ready.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: (to the old Senator) Come, Brother Senator, your company may be useful.

div.stage: Exeunt all but Olivia, La. Temptyouth, Ariana, Lucinda, and Gervatio.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: So Ladies, how d'ye like my Contrivance? Bondi may stir, but the duce a bit will he get his Lordship released to night, and to morrow I have another Plot, which I hope makes my fair Mistress happy.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Thou art my better Angel.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: But my Ariana, won't you give me leave to free my Lord, provided I take care he never troubles you with love again?

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Ay, get him into the Bonds of Matrimony with Lucinda, and free him from his Prison as soon as you please.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Methinks 'tis pity the pretty Creature should be condemn'd to such a Fop.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Oh, a rich Fool was alwaies my desire, that I might show my Discretion in managing him and his Estate.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Nay, if you are pleased I am.

sp.speaker: La. Tem.
sp.p: Come Child, we have many Irons in the Fire, there's not a Senator but I have done a good turn for some time or other, and therefore I fear not succeeding.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Your Servant, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Yours.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Come in Gentlemen, the old Enemy's gone.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Let me embrace thee, thou Soul of Ingenuity and Goodness.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Indeed Gervatio has proved just contrary to my Expectations; I hope as he has freed Ariana, if I crave his Friendship, I may obtain it; I am sure you know what moves my Lord to use me so intolerably, that I can never meet a civil Answer.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: I own I know the Cause, but dare not tell ye, lest it startle ye too much.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: No, Gervatio, prithee speak, for his brutal Carriage is past enduring.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Then, Madam, my Master was never blind, pretended it, only to avoid the being President of Dalmatia; consider if you have urg'd him.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Not blind!

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Then I am lost.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Look up, Olivia, Danger shall never reach thee whilst this Arm can weild a Sword.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Madam, your Apprehension is too timerous.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: All here are your ready Friends.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Oh, 'tis impossible, my Ruine is inevitable, the innocent Freedom I have given this young Lord, my Virgin Love, before my Husband Bondi, will be punisht with nothing less than Death, Italy produces no milder Vengeance for suspected Wives.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Harbour not a Thought so terrible; rather than be punish'd guiltless, fly. Venice with your faithful Slave; to break forc'd Vows Heaven can never hold a Crime, my Life, and whatsoever I am Master of, is yours.

sp.speaker: Oliv
sp.p: Alas, how wild you talk! five noble Brothers adorn my Family, who wou'd pursue my guilty Steps, and piecemeal on this wretched Body hew out my Honours Stains and their Revenge.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Faith Invention pours on me like a Deluge, for your Protection and endless Favour, I'le undertake to bring ye both off.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Impossible.
What a mad Risque our Sex runs when we plunge in real Guilt! what Pangs, what Agonies, what Terrors are the fatal Consequence!

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Hast thou Reason, Gervatio, for what thou say'st?

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: I'll serve you all, and, I do not doubt, successfully.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Which Room is the Family in?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: I tremble, there's my Lord.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Away, Gentlemen, into the Garden agen, stay in the Grotto, I'll be with ye presently, and tell ye all my Designs.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: We'll wait you there.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Good Ladies, to your Closets, I would talk with my Lord alone.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Come, dear Ariana, thou art happy in prospect of thy love; if mine had been my Lot, these Mischiefs ne'er had hapned.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: I wish your mind at peace.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: God I have undertook Hercules's labour, but the greator the Undertaking, the greater the Glory in the performance.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Oh Gervatio! there's no freeing of this Fool to night; where's my damn'd, Wife and Daughter?

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Gone to undress themselves.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: There's no body with 'em.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: None but theis Utensils, their Chambermaids.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Gervatio, I hitherto have trusted thee with all the Secrets of my life, shrink not back when I disclose the greatest: My Wife has certainly abused me, her Relations are so numerous, that to expose her I should run ten thousand hazards therefore I have resolved silently and secretly to take her off by Poison, to stop my Shame and her future Sins.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: If it be so, my assistance shan't be wanting, but, Sir, the Case is weighty, the Breath of life blown out, Repentance cannot kindle the dead Coal agen.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: That's true, but I am by all her wanton Carriages convinc'd, besides a thousand Circumstances, she's guilty.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Well, more to confirm your Suspicion, I must confess I heard 'em appoint a meeting in the Garden about some three hours hence.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Oh, damn 'em, damn 'em.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: From the Balcony we may overhear and discovet new Cause for your Revenge, or else find her innocent.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Innocence! 'tis not in the Sex, Eve lost it when she lewdly listen'd to the Fiend, and intail'd her guilt on her Posterity.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Have patience, and your own Ears shall either acquit or condemn her.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Nay, my Eyes have seen enough already. Well, Gervatio, I trust to thee, and will be ready when you call me.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Your Lordship ever found me faithful.

If I do deliver these Ladies from all their Fears, I ought at least to be esteem'd a Knight Errant, and have it inscrib'd upon my Tomb; Here lies a most puissant Hero: Pox on't, what will rhime to Hero? No, it shall be thus:
The generous Gervatio here lies dead,
To whom for Aid distressed Damsels fled. Ay, ay, that will do: Now for my Garden-Sparks, my Instruments are Lords.

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth ACT.

div.head: ACT V.
div.stage: Bondi and Gervatio appear in the Balcony, a Curtain to draw.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: THey are not come yet, but I'm sure they will, for my Tormentor seem'd very uneasie, and full of Thought.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: See, my Lord, they both appear.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Contagion seize 'em, Mildews and Blasts destroy her Beauty, stamp her Face as deform'd as her Soul, for, a Plague on her, she's too handsom now.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: ●ay, my Lord, if you are thus passionate, they'l hear us.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Hist, I have done.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Madam, I come to wait on your Commands, which, how strange soever, blindly I obey.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: A Pox of your Complaisance.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, be silent.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: I am, I am.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: When your Duty to your Father took you from my Wishes, and gave you to the noble Bed of Bondi, great were my pangs; I struggled hard to conquer Love's fierce Fires, and turn 'em into Friendship's lambent Flames; strong was the Contest, yet I overcame, and now can boast a Friendship to you and your Lord.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Pho, this is Dissimulation.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Hear 'em out, I am sure they see not us.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: I knew your Friendship pure, else I had never trusted you so far; but my Designs are ended now, and my Lord grows very peevish; lest your coming should offend him, I beg you would forbear the House, or any Opportunity of speaking to me.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Madam, I will even in this fulfill your pleasure; but you was pleased to promise, when you made that odd Request, I would in appearance seem your Gallant, that you would some time tell me the reason of that innocent Deceit.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: I did, but 'tis a Secret, and I must have your Word and Honour, that neither Friend nor Foe extort it from you.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: I give you both, nay, upon my Soul I will not utter it.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Then know my Lord was never blind.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Ha, Gervatio?

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Sure she's a Witch.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: What is hid from loving Eyes? tho' all the world believed it, I perceived the contrary, and often urged my Husband, tho' not plainly contradicting what he said, yet round about he might perceive I guess'd at it.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Did my Lady ever hint she thought you not blind?

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: At first she was damn'd inquisitive, which I still thought she did for her security in sinning.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: It sounds like truth: But hush, they go on.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Methought I had no Comfort of my Life, whilst my dear Lord but seem'd under that Affliction; besides, Heaven knows, I feard a real Judgment might befall him for his Counterfeiting, and so I plaid a thousand tricks with you, thinking his Love so strong that he could not bear to see, and pretend not to see another invade his right in me? This is the story, and this was my design, but my Lord by his own Contrivance now is himself again, and I renew my request to see you no more, for considering past Actions, your sight makes my Husband uneasie. When I find him in a good humour I will acquaint him with my guiltless project.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: And if he is not displeased I may hope to continue in the Enjoyment of your Friendship.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Of that hereafter, but my Lady Temptyouth I resolve to avoid, because she knew not the bottom of my design, yet was so free to forward it, my Lord your Servant.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Madam, yours; on this fair hand let me wish you everlasting Happiness.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Remember 'tis your parting kiss, and this indeed your eternal leave.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: My Love must mitigate that rigour, besides, our Friend Gervatio has Imployment for me in the House.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: By all my dangers (which I hope are past) I will no more endeavour or consent to see you. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: What think ye now, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Bind.
sp.p: Faith, I know not what to think, were I fare you have not betray'd me, there may be some truth in't.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Who I, my Lord? Upon my life not I, why your Lordship knows I never could abide the Ladies; how many times have I made you angry with 'em. I'm sure they hate me.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: That's true; if she forbears his sight I'll forbear my revenge, tho' the Letters and the Kisses grumble in my Gizard still.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Pshaw, only to carry on her Plot.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Well, I'll believe it if I can, 'twill be most for my ease I am sure— Come let's in, I'll write to the Duke for this Scribling Lord, tho' in troth I am almost asham'd to appear in't.
Go thy ways Don 〈◊〉; my drubbing will be reveng'd at last.

div.stage: Enter to Lord Insulls, Lady Temptyouth, Lucinda, and a Keeper.

sp.speaker: La. Tempt.
sp.p: You see my Authority.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Yes, and obey it; the Prisoner is at your Service.

sp.speaker: La. Tempt.
sp.p: My Lord, your Lordship's humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: O Heavens! your Ladiship and that brightness see me in this vile Condition, I don't believe I have a Grain of Powder in my Wigg, the Villains that took away my Papers took my Mirrour also, because 'twas set in Gold, now I could wish my self in the darkest Dungeon rather than appear such a Brute before those resistless Eyes.

sp.speaker: La. Tempt.
sp.p: Alas, poor Girl, I am sure she never did any thing of this Nature before, but she received such a vast respect for your Lordship; your behaviour carries in it a shining Complaisance so much above our dull Venetians, that no wonder it touched a tender Breast.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: I would serve the French if I met with any of the Nation in the Person of a Labourer or Beggar, and sure when a Cavalier is in Affliction, who may justly beast of all the Accomplishments of mankind, 'twill excuse my breaking the strict rules of Decency in giving him a visit.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: I am Transported, such sounds are only fit for Angels to hear, Mortals cannot bear the Joy.

sp.speaker: La. Tempt.
sp.p: Nay, she has brought you a Present too, and I hope a welcome one, your Liberty.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: No, the Lady has brought me everlasting Chains, by the Muses (Confound the Oath, I cannot leave it) I'd not leave 'em to be free as Air.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: What means your Lordship, I am sure I begg'd your Freedom heartily of my Uncle, the Duke.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: But your Eyes teach my Heart the pleasing Bondage, which I desire to Triumph for ever. God I say abundance of fine things.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Your Lordship forgets, 'tis not Ariana you are talking to.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: No, if it were, every word shou'd stick in my Throat, she a dull Insensible, no Mein, no Air, no Song, no Dance, nothing agreeable.

sp.speaker: La. Tempt.
sp.p: Oh, the abominable Fool! how he describes the prettiest Creature Nature ever made.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Your Lordship cannot be in earnest.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p:
By the Infernals, (Ay, they'll do me less harm than the Muses) But vast Fortune if I had married her, which now I never will: 'Twas for her that my Equippage might have been the finest at the Court of Versailles:
My Coach drawn by six Barbs, six Blacks to every Horse. The poor Creature my Wife I'd have confined to the Country with a pair of broken winded Jades and an old Fashion'd Chariot.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: I don't like your usage of a Wife my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: She has us'd me ill and deserves such a return, but if your Ladiship wou'd think me worthy, Heavens! you shou'd shine the Glory of Versailles; The Barbs be yours, and I the humblest of your Slaves.
How fine is that, the Prison sure inspires me.

sp.speaker: La. Tempt.
sp.p: Nay, I can't excuse Ariana, for I doubt she had more than a Finger in this troublesome business, but my Girl's too young to think of Love, tho' I wish she had never seen your Lordship; I know not what time may produce.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: Pardon my Presumption; I had not broke upon the Lady so abruptly, but I am prest upon by Fate, my Father to morrow arrives at Venice expecting me to marry Ariana? Cou'd I have hoped such Happiness as to have chang'd my Destiny and fixt here where all my wishes tend, my Father might storm, but 'twou'd not be in his power to alter it.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Oh Heavens, such a concern ventur'd on so suddenly wou'd kill me with the Apprehension.

sp.speaker: La. Tempt.
sp.p: Come, let's leave this detested place and go to my House, there we'll consider further.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: I wait on you, Madam, with unexpressible thanks for this Favour: I hope I shall hear of my people, that I may once again appear like a Man of Quality; not like a Rat shut up in a hole. I profess I am scarce fit to touch that fair hand.

sp.speaker: La. Tempt.
sp.p: But indeed you are, my Lord! Lucinda.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: My Mothers Commands, my Lord.

div.stage: He at his Table Sealing Letters, two Servants.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: This to the Duke, this to Gonsalvo, I hope they'll consider my Lord's a Fool, and release him: He make the Libel! I found by his discourse he made it no more than I did. (Exeunt Servants He's foolish 'tis true, but then he is rich and the fitter for a Husband.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Oh, Sir!

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Of, my dear!

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: What's the matter with the Women?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Alas, d'ye hear no noise in the House?

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Noise, what noise, not I.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Why all your Moveables are seizing: Two Priests with Officers walk o'er the House, nor will they be controul'd, proudly they march along and break open all the Locks, set down your Plate, your rich Hangings, and every thing of Value, my dressing Plate that was my Maiden Treasure, that's down too; Oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Nay, as much as my ●old Bodkins, and all the Jewels I have on: I shall be a 〈◊〉 Luss now! Oh, Heavens.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Ye amaze me, what can be the meaning on't?

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: They ' ll tell no body, but seem to have great Authority.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: I am at my Wits end. Where's Gervatio?

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Here comes the sorrowfull Man.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Oh, that ever I shou'd live to see this day! such Havock, such Waste there will be of my dear Masters Goods, wou'd I were dead out of the sight on't.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Why Gervatio, is all the World mad? What is the reason of all this Outrage?

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: I know not, but your Enemies are at my heels, I suppose they'll acquaint you: Here they come, my Lord.

div.stage: Enter Count Andrea, and Fidelio, disguiss'd like Friars, and their Servants like Officers.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Has Heaven nothing but Afflictions for this aged Head! Reverend Fathers what have I done to deserve such Usage.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Officers give us the Inventory and retire: We will yet, respecting his grey Hairs, conceal his shame and crimes as much as possible: Brother will you lay the Enormous fa●it open before his hardned Soul.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Your Eloquence will do it more feelingly Brother.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Excuse me, indeed your Capacity is largest.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Pardon me, I am weak, very weak, compar'd to you.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Ah, the Devil take ye both and your Civilities.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Then according to my poor Ability.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: How I am tortur'd.

sp.speaker: Andrea Coughing and Hearing.
sp.p: Melito Bondi, Thou stand'st accused before the Duke and Senate, and his Holinesses Nuncio, for such a grand Deceit, for a Crime of such a Nature, so black in it's Root, so wide in its Branches, the Parent a lie, the Daughter's Hypocrisie, Dissimulation to the highest degree even to Perjury: Brother be pleased to discuss.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: What will become of me.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Well, may'st thou tremble, old man, who durst affront Heaven in Counterfeiting blindness.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Ah, Lord!

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Ah, we are all undone.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: But as one Crime seldom fails to pull a greater on, in thee, lost man, we find the dire proof of all that's ill; to restore this sight which Heaven knows was never lost, Silvester's Sacred Girdle must be fetched, and a Miracle pretended; but know the Saint needs not by your studied lies, addition to his well established Glory, since the curst falsity has been broached, he has rous'd him in his Peacefull shrine and waked the Convent with his cries, Bondi's a dissembler, Bondi has done me wrong, Bondi must be punished.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Worthy Fathers, behold at your Feet a Penitent, have pity on my lost Estate.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Rise, and hear us out? Brother, proceed.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: For this Crime the Senate have decreed, the Nuncio too concurring, that thou Melito Bondi be straight Devested of thy Lands and rich Possession, thy Moveables, thy Debts, and whatsoever's thine Confiscated to the State, thy self still to remain a Prisoner for life.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: The doom is mild and merciful, if thou hadst fallen where the Inquisition Reigns, through what variety of Torments must you have past, and for conclusion, died: Brother, will you urge any thing further.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Good Reverendissimo's, let me beg you cease, see my poor Master is just expiring under the severity of your censure: your selves, I am sure, want refreshing too.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Truly my Spirits are exhausted.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: I do perceive mine evaporate.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Within I have prepared something to sustain nature.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Let me entreat ye Fathers to accept it.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Shall we venture to eat the Viands of the Hypocrite.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: For that matter I'll be your taster, pray walk in.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: My Stomach calleth upon me to venture: Old Gentleman, we shall quickly return and examine your Papers.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: What you please, I am humbled to any thing.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: (Complementing about the way) Nay Brother, that will not do.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Upon my Veracity you shall.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: By my order I won't.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: That's Sacred; then I must.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: How have you come off, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: e'en stript of all, naked in my old age, as when I first peept in this wicked world.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Ah me, Unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Unfortunate indeed, bred high and not worth a Drachma, I doubt that handsome Face will tempt you to make the best on't Ariana, and rather than live poorly Sacrifice thy virtue.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Think better of me, I'll die first.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Why, that's well said, as for my Wife, she I fear, has learnt her Trade already.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Why must I suffer all these unkind suspicions?

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Nay, I forgive thee, be it how it will, and thou shan't hear of it any more from me.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Shall we go and intercede with these cruel Men.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: I kneel, and beg, and pray as long as I can speak for my poor Father.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Ay, you are wondrous kind.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Come, let us try our power.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Hold, ye Fools, did ye ever know or hear of an Italian Priest let go his prey; no, no, my long hoarded Wealth is got into Hucksters hands, I may e'en bid farewell to all my possessions.

div.p: Oh, Gervatio, my Foes I know are still innexorable, and my ruin resolved.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Yonder they are Nuckle deep in Sweet-meats, and have the best Wines the world affords before 'em, yet I perceive no signs of mollifying: My Lord, I would in private tell your Lordship what I have thought on.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: If you please, Madam, we'll in and do all we can wish for my Father's deliverance.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Ay, most heartily.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Ah, Gervatio.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Alas, my Lord.

sp.speaker: ●●nd.
sp.p: But who may I thank for all this, who was at the bottom of the blind Contrivance that has ruined me.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: And pray who would have thought a dead Saint would have distur●●● himself with telling tales.

sp.speaker: Bind.
sp.p: Ah, I rather fear 'twas living Devils, 'tis no matter, I have resolved in 〈◊〉 Afflictions to submit to every thing, and neither quarrel nor complain, though I discover thee and the Wife of my Bosom, two Serpents.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: A resigning Will is a great blessing; for my own part, I am sure the Innocence of a Dove is upon me, towards your Honour, even at this time, when you are suspecting me, my poor Brain is in Labour for your good.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: There's neither help nor hope remain.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Yet we may make the best of a bad Market.
My folly appears so plain, I am ashamed to apply my self to the Duke 〈◊〉 Senate.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: I meant not so, that must be done he rea●ter, but you know my Lord, these Harpies have not yet examined your Papers, I am sure they are tied● by the Teeth for stirring one while: now if you dare trust me I can take out Bonds and Mortgages, to the Sum of fifty thousand Crowns, get it setled first upon my young Lady Ariana, yet not let her know it, then it can give her no encouragement for disobedience.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: I thank thy care, Gervatio, and will instantly put them into thy hands, but, dost hear, let the Lawyer put in some doubtfull Clause, that if I shou'd by any means escape, I may re-asume my Right and Title to it again.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: I warrant you, my Lord, tho' her name secures it from the Law, she shall be ne'er the better for it.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Come, make haste.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: My Lord, that way you'll meet the Moabites.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: (starting) My Woes distract me, I scarce know where my Closet is.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: So, Gervatio has work'd him to his Ends, 'tis a lucky fellow I protest, I hope Heaven will forgive me for consenting these tricks should be plaid with my old Father, since my end is honest and for the sake of my Fidelio, who merits more than I can obtain for him.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Why, the Sparks did it rarely, but I am sorry Count Andrea has an opportunity of seeing me again.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Pho, there's no harm in his sight, you should not fall too hastily from one degree to another.

div.stage: Enter Count Andrea and Fidelio, in their own Cloathes.
div.p: Here comes the Reverendissimo's, as Gervatio call'd them: Does the Wheel of Affairs run smooth.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Upon Carpet ground my life, Gervatio has pick'd all the best of the Bonds, Mortgages, &c. and is gone to an Eminent Lawyer with 'em.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: What have ye done with my Father.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Made bold to imprison him in his own Closet, where he must remain during our Royal Pleasure, and now, Madam, it rests wholly in your generous breast to compleat my Happiness; Gervatio has secured the Chaplain ours, if you consent not to what indeed makes me giddy with the vast Joy, giving me your Beauteous self, this very moment some sinister accident in all probability will ruin our designs.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Nay my dear Ariana you have gone too far now to shrink back, come we'll be witnesses.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Well, Fidelio, I will venture on this B●g-bear-Marriage, but if thou shouldst prove ungratefull after all my obligations, what punishment dost thou deserve.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: To be despised by the World, proclaim'd a Coward; and what's yet greater be hated by you.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Whilst I behold another's Happiness, my wretched self am banished for ever from what my soul admires.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: How do ye know 'tis for ever young Gentleman? I may out live my Lord, then a brisk Widow weigh'd down with Bags, oh, 'tis an excellent Cordial for the younger branch of a Family.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Ay there is comfort in that thought, if you wou'd in the mean time allow me to see you; nothing less will preserve my life till the rich Cordial 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: To preserve my own I must deny that, for Gervatio tells me, my Lord was growing up to great extremities; your forbearance of any sort of address, ● shall esteem as a proof of your affection, but whilst we are idly talking here, Fidelio views us with impatient Eyes, and longs to have his Joys secured; the Marriage over, I must beg your Lordship to retire, I would not have my Husband see you for the world.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Howe'er unwilling, those commanding Eyes tell me I must obey.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Come, Ariana,
sp.l: The Priest our hands, but Heaven our hearts shall join,
And endless raptures Crown me when I call thee mine.

div.stage: Enter Lady Temptyouth, Lord Insulls, and Lucinda.

sp.speaker: La. Temp.
sp.p: Well I never thought any Mortal cou'd have prevailed with me to have parted with this dear Girl at so short warning, and without more consideration, but your Lordships merit is irresistible.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: I am blest in possessing her, punish me with the beastly Garb of the Vulgar, if I would be unmarried to be an Emperour. This visit is in Triumph to let proud Ariana see what an excelling Beauty has made me happy. O my dear Cherubin, I can't but think how the Court of France will admire my choice.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Shall you like that.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: Covet it; I hope, Madam, you will rob the Ladies of all their Sparks, and the whole Gallantry of the Court be made to you.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Nay, if your Lordship Glories in my Conquests, fear not, they shall be numerous, I never fail'd when I endeavour'd it.
That's true, for my hearts your prize, which, by the Muses, is a Trophy not to be despised.

div.stage: Enter Gervatio, with Parchment in his hands.

sp.speaker: La. Temp.
sp.p: Gervatio, where's the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, my young Lady is commiting Matrimony, I believe, that sweet meat that's commonly attended with sowre sawce.

sp.speaker: La. Temp.
sp.p: Is she so, much Joy I wish her.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: I must to my old Master, get him to set his hand to these, and then I think this head has brought wonders to pass.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: Who is my Rival, some ill-drest Fellow I'll lay my life on't.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Even that robust piece of rudeness that accosted your Lordship so odly, Count Fidelio.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: He, he, he, they are well matched, by the Muses, I believe neither of 'em understand the French way of dressing so well as the Groom of my Horses, he, he, he.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Ariana always ridicul'd it, which has often broke Friendship between us.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: Heavens, if I had married her, what a world of labour wou'd it have cost me to have modell'd her for the drawing room at Versailles, whilst you, my dear, at first sight will appear the abstract of Perfection.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: My Lord, you make me blush, but I shall now take unusual care in my dress, that your Lordship may think me agreeable.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: Happy man, happy man, as ever put on the yoke of Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Ha, my Lord Insulls, your very humble Servant, this is too transporting an hour to remember anger, now the dear Ariana's mine, our Quarrel dies.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: I wish you Joy with her, I am provided as much to my satisfaction, be pleased to know the Duke's Neice for my Wife.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Lucinda, the Dukes Neice.

sp.speaker: La. Temp.
sp.p: (Aside to Ariana) Hold dear Ariana, spoil not this day's Mirth with a discovery, he'll know it soon enough; besides, I'll make thee, poor Girl, worth more than that Fool deserve.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: I beg your Pardon, I am dumb.
Madam, we must humour the greatness it seems.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: With all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: This is their Venetian breeding to whisper half an hour: Poyson me, my dear, if the very sight on't is not enough to spoil a Man.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: Joy to your honour, I thought you wou'd not have ventured to have changed your condition so suddenly.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: Your Ladyship might consider the Man, and that would take your Wonder off.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Was ever any such Vanity.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Then you say you've obtained I may walk about my House till further order.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: (sees the Company) Heyday, who have we here, nothing but meeting and revelling, this is a time indeed for Mirth!

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: Old Gentleman, I am married, but not to thy Daughter, and for that reason will be merry in spire of thy b●●d.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: (Ariana kneeling) And I am married to her, and for that happiness shall be for ever joyfull.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Trick'd, Ruin'd, Undone; hold, not ruin'd neither, he has ne'er a 〈◊〉, nor none he shall have.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Then I must interpose; if you have no Bowels for such a sweet young Couple, I have had; my Lord Fidelio, here's the value of fifty thousand Crowns, come, that will make a shift till the old man pops aside, or something better happens.
Betray'd by 〈◊〉, I will run mad, I will grow distracted quickly.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: My Lord, if you did but see how ill such starts of passion suit your age, sure you won'd forbear.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Think, my Lord, my want of fortune may be made up in tenderness towards your Daughter, and duty towards your self.

sp.speaker: La. Temp.
sp.p: Come, come, my Lord, the Senate, no doubt, when they see him married to Ariana, will honour him with places of trust and profit, a rising Man seldom wants a hand to help him higher.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Let me consider, all in this room have been my Foes, I think, every individual Person, for what cause, even because I have been a cross stingy old Captious fellow, but henceforth I'll throw it away as fast as the best of ●e; Alas, I had forgot, I have nothing but Misfortunes, and am a wretched Prisoner Condemned to Shame and Poverty.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: All those afflictions I'll take off upon condition you'll forgive your worthy Son and Daughter.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Do this, and we all are Friends.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Then my Lord, be satisfied, the Duke nor Senate know nothing of your deceit, 'twas only a Contrivance of your humble Servant to oblige this young Lord and my Charming Mistress.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Well, thou hast proved a great Rogue, but I'll keep my word.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Then I hope we shall not kneel again in vain.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: No, take my Blessing, and as you prove, an Addition to her Fortune.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I have all my heart 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: And my future life shall make amends for venturing once to disobey my Father.

sp.speaker: La. Temp.
sp.p: Now all's well, I hope the Musick I ordered will come that we may conclude our Joys with a Dance.

sp.speaker: Ins.
sp.p: By all means, let us have Musick that I may have the pleasure to see my Lucinda trip like a Fairy.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.p: My Lord, as this is a general Jubilee, I hope I shall partake it, and heart burnings being laid aside we henceforth may live more quietly.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Yes, yes, according to your deportment, thou hast been! Uh, uh, but I have promised to say no more.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Gervatio, I will always call thee Friend, and serve thee with my Life and Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.p: Nor will I forget to esteem and reward thee.

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: I hope you will say I have proved a well-meaning man to all, and my old Master forgive me.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Aye, aye, that I will for fear thou shouldst play me any more tricks.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Here's the Musick.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Now let's in and taste a Glass of Wine, I want some comfort after all my frights.
sp.l: And may my Fate to each a warning give,
How they e'er love or practice to deceive;
For tho' they prosper and their Cheat's believ'd
With ease you see deceivers are deceiv'd,

div.head: EPILOGUE.
Spoken by Miss Bradshaw.
div.l: I'm sent a small Embassadress for Grace,
If there was power in such a Childish face:
Who knows but artless innocence may move,
And looks unpractic'd sometimes catch your Love.
Suppose it so, 'tis now, alass, too late,
Your liking me wards not the blow of fate.
A begging Epilogue's a despairing Case;
'Tis asking mercy when the doom is past.
Part of this Play though stoln was lately shown,
And what was once expos'd to this Lewd Town
Tho 'twere improv'd with you 'twill scarce go down.
yet 'twould be nobler not to be severe,
And what has been unjustly rifled spare;
For my sake use her kindly once again,
Pray do, you good natured, ●ine, pretty Men,
Come, I shall grow a Woman e'er't be long,
'Tis but a little while we are too young;
And if Heaven on my youth does Charms bestow,
I'll layout all the stick in pleasing you.
Let our wrong'd Author in your Favour shine,
And when you wish it, you shan't fail of mine.

div.head: EPILOGUE:
Design'd for Mr. Verbruggen.
div.l: NOw Britain's raging Wars are at an end,
Caesar adorns the Throne he did defend;
Eternal Peace is fix'd, and all things smile,
To Crown the happy blessings of our Isle:
From hence, we have encouragement to expect,
The Stage with nobler off'rings shall be deck'd;
For in past Ages Peace did Wit create,
And Poets flourish'd equal to the state.
'Twas when the great Augustus rul'd in Peace
And all mankind from him enjoyn'd sweet ease:
Ovid's soft genius first began to please.
'Twas then the Lyrick Horace, Son of Fame,
Compil'd his works, immortal as his Name,
Soft ●ase and quiet fancy did infuse,
And Rome's blest state gave Birth to Virgil's Muse.
Oh, may our state like that produce such Men,
That from the crop of their luxuriant Pen,
Succeeding Ages may for ever glean.
Criticks their nature then shall alter quite
And what they fain would damn shall praise in spite.
Poets no more in humble lines shall sue
And creep and cringe to steal applause from you,
Nor beg for Favour where no Favour's due:
No more shall sense in fustian lines be lost,
Nor dullness flourish at the Actor's cost.
Authors shall write with fancy unconfin'd
To Copy Nature and reform Mankind,
Then Wit and sense shall here for ever dwell,
And Britain's Stage shall Athen's far excel
